Identification.LongTitle: Rules for Regulating the Practice and Procedure in the Federal Court of Appeal and the Federal Court

Provision.Text: Whereas, pursuant to subsection 46(4)a of the Federal Court Act, a copy of the proposed Federal Court Rules, 1998 was published in the Canada Gazette Part I on September 20, 1997 and interested persons were invited to make representations with respect to the proposed Rules;

Therefore, His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Justice, pursuant to subsection 46(1)b of the Federal Court Act, hereby approves the annexed Federal Court Rules, 1998, made by the rules committee of the Federal Court of Canada on January 26, 1998.

Section.Text: These Rules may be cited as the Federal Courts Rules.

Subsection.Text: These Rules apply to all proceedings in the Federal Court of Appeal and the Federal Court unless otherwise provided by or under an Act of Parliament.
In the event of any inconsistency between these Rules and an Act of Parliament or a regulation made under such an Act, that Act or regulation prevails to the extent of the inconsistency.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Rules.

Definition.Text: Act means the Federal Courts Act.
action means a proceeding referred to in rule 169.
address for service means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a party who has no solicitor of record,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the address shown on the last document filed by the party that indicates an address in Canada, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the party is the Crown or the Attorney General of Canada, the office of the Deputy Attorney General of Canada in Ottawa; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a party who has a solicitor of record, the address of the solicitor of record shown on the last filed document that indicates an address.

Definition.Text: Administrator means the Chief Administrator appointed under section 5 of the Courts Administration Service Act, or a person acting on his or her behalf.
Admiralty action means an action in which the Court exercises jurisdiction under section 22 of the Act.
appeal means a proceeding referred to in rule 335.

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of an application that has been certified as a class proceeding, includes a person on whose behalf an application is commenced; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application that has been certified as a class proceeding, means

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of the common questions of law or fact, the representative applicant, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of individual questions, the member to whom those questions apply.

Definition.Text: application means a proceeding referred to in rule 300.
assessment officer means an officer of the Registry designated by an order of the Court, a judge or a prothonotary, and includes, in respect of a reference, the referee presiding in the reference.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: juge responsable de la gestion de l’instance

Definition.Text: case management judge means a judge assigned under paragraph 383(a) or rule 383.1 and includes a prothonotary assigned under paragraph 383(b).
certified copy, in respect of a document in the custody of the Registry, means a copy of the document certified by an officer of the Registry.
Christmas recess means the period beginning on December 21 in a year and ending on January 7 in the following year.
Court means, as the circumstances require,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Federal Court of Appeal, including, in respect of a motion, a single judge of that court; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Federal Court, including a prothonotary acting within the jurisdiction conferred under these Rules.

Definition.Text: Court file means the file maintained pursuant to rule 23 or 24.
dispute resolution conference means a conference ordered under rule 386.
filed, in respect of a document, means accepted for filing under rule 72.
garnishee means a person in respect of whom an order attaching a debt to a judgment debtor has been made under rule 449.
Hague Convention means the Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters signed at The Hague on November 15, 1965.
hearing includes a conference held under these Rules.
holiday means a Saturday, Sunday or any other day defined as a holiday in subsection 35(1) of the Interpretation Act.
intervener means a person who has been granted status as an intervener under rule 109.
issued means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an originating document, dated, signed, sealed with the seal of the Court and assigned a Court file number by the Administrator; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of any other document, dated, signed and sealed with the seal of the Court by the Administrator.

Definition.Text: local office means an office of the Registry of the Court established by the Administrator other than the principal office.
motion means a request to the Court under, or to enforce, these Rules.
oath includes a solemn affirmation within the meaning of subsection 14(1) of the Canada Evidence Act.
order includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judgment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a decision or other disposition of a tribunal; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a determination of a reference under section 18.3 of the Act.

Definition.Text: originating document means a document referred to in rule 63.
party means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an action, a plaintiff, defendant or third party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an application,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: where a tribunal brings a reference under section 18.3 of the Act, a person who becomes a party in accordance with rule 323,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the Attorney General of Canada brings a reference under section 18.3 of the Act, the Attorney General of Canada and any other person who becomes a party in accordance with rule 323, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in any other case, an applicant or respondent;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an appeal, an appellant or respondent; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a motion, the person bringing the motion or a respondent thereto.

Definition.Text: person includes a tribunal, an unincorporated association and a partnership.

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of an action that has been certified as a class proceeding, includes a person on whose behalf an action is commenced; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an action that has been certified as a class proceeding, means

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of the common questions of law or fact, the representative plaintiff, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of individual questions, the member to whom those questions apply.

Definition.Text: pleading means a document in a proceeding in which a claim is initiated, defined, defended or answered.
principal office means the head office of the Registry of the Court established by the Administrator.
referee means a person to whom a matter has been referred under rule 153.

sheriff includes a marshal, peace officer or other person to whom a writ, warrant or other process is directed and, in the Province of Quebec, a member of the Ordre professionnel des huissiers de justice du Québec.
simplified action means an action referred to in rule 292.
solicitor means a person referred to in subsection 11(3) of the Act.
solicitor of record means a solicitor determined under rule 123.
specially managed proceeding means a proceeding managed in accordance with rules 383 to 385.
statement of claim means a document by which an action is commenced.
summer recess means the months of July and August in each year.
swear, in respect of an oath, includes affirm.
third party includes a fourth or subsequent party.
tribunal has the same meaning as federal board, commission or other tribunal in the Act.
unincorporated association means an organization of two or more persons, other than a partnership, that operates under a common name for a common purpose or undertaking.
writ of execution includes a writ of seizure and sale, a writ of possession, a writ of delivery and a writ of sequestration, and any further writ in aid thereof.

Section.Text: These Rules shall be interpreted and applied so as to secure the just, most expeditious and least expensive determination of every proceeding on its merits.

On motion, the Court may provide for any procedural matter not provided for in these Rules or in an Act of Parliament by analogy to these Rules or by reference to the practice of the superior court of the province to which the subject-matter of the proceeding most closely relates.
Where these Rules require that a form be used, the form may incorporate any variations that the circumstances require.

Heading.TitleText: Computation, Extension and Abridgement of Time

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the computation of time under these Rules, or under an order of the Court, is governed by sections 26 to 30 of the Interpretation Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Period of less than seven days
Subsection.Text: Where a period of less than seven days is provided for in these Rules or fixed by an order of the Court, a day that is a holiday shall not be included in computing the period.
Unless otherwise directed by the Court, a day that falls within the Christmas recess shall not be included in the computation of time under these Rules for filing, amending or serving a document.
Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a period provided by these Rules may be extended once by filing the consent in writing of all parties.
An extension of a period under subsection (1) shall not exceed one half of the period sought to be extended.
No extension may be made on consent of the parties in respect of a period fixed by an order of the Court or under subsection 203(1), 304(1) or 339(1).
On motion, the Court may extend or abridge a period provided by these Rules or fixed by an order.
A motion for an extension of time may be brought before or after the end of the period sought to be extended.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Motions for extension in Court of Appeal
Subsection.Text: Unless the Court directs otherwise, a motion to the Federal Court of Appeal for an extension of time shall be brought in accordance with rule 369.

The Administrator shall arrange that there be in attendance at every sitting of the Court a duly qualified person to act as court registrar for the sitting, who shall, subject to the direction of the Court,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make all arrangements necessary to conduct the sitting in an orderly, efficient and dignified manner;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a record of every material event that transpires during the sitting;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: keep and be responsible for all books and records of the Court used at the sitting; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: keep and be responsible for all exhibits filed during the sitting and mark them, record them and indicate by whom they were filed.

Subsection.Text: The Administrator shall arrange for the attendance at every sitting of the Court of all persons who are necessary for the proper conduct of the Court at the sitting.
The seal of each court — the Federal Court of Appeal and the Federal Court — shall be approved by its Chief Justice and shall be kept in the principal office.
The Chief Justice of each court may authorize one or more facsimiles of the seal of their court to be kept at the Registry.

Section.Text: Registry functions may be performed by an officer of the Registry at any place and at any time.

To provide the public with an opportunity to make comments regarding the administration or rules of the Court, two small locked boxes — one for the Federal Court of Appeal and one for the Federal Court — shall be maintained in every office of the Registry, located and constructed so that members of the public can conveniently insert envelopes into them and identified by a sign indicating

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE FEDERAL COURT OF APPEAL” or “RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE FEDERAL COURT”, as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that recommendations are invited for amendments to the Federal Courts Rules and improvements in the administration of the Court; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that every recommendation will be sent unopened directly to the Chief Justice of the court in question.

Section.Text: The principal office is located in Ottawa and local offices are located in Calgary, Charlottetown, Edmonton, Fredericton, Halifax, Iqaluit, Montreal, Quebec City, Regina, Saint John, Saskatoon, St. John’s, Toronto, Vancouver, Whitehorse, Winnipeg and Yellowknife.
A request or requisition to the Administrator under these Rules shall be made in Form 18.
A party shall pay to the Registry for a service or procedure set out in Tariff A the fees set out in that Tariff.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a sheriff is entitled to the fees for service and disbursements set out in Tariff A.
On motion, the Court may increase or decrease the fee payable to a sheriff on execution.

Section.Text: The Administrator shall keep all records necessary for documenting the proceedings of the Court and enter in them all orders, directions, foreign judgments ordered to be registered, pleadings and other documents filed in a proceeding.

Subsection.Text: The Administrator shall keep in the Registry a caveat register, in which all caveats, withdrawals of caveats and orders affecting caveats shall be entered.
On the filing of a caveat under subsection 493(1), (2) or (3), the Administrator shall enter the caveat in the caveat register.

For each proceeding of the Court, the Administrator shall keep a file that is composed of the following documents, each marked with its date and time of filing, and that is organized by order of filing:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every document filed under these Rules, an order of the Court or an Act of Parliament, other than affidavits or other material filed in support of a motion or as evidence at trial;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all correspondence between a party and the Registry;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all orders;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: copies of all writs issued in the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: such other documents relating to the proceeding as the Court may direct.

Subsection.Text: The Administrator shall keep an annex to each Court file that is comprised of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all affidavits;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all exhibits; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all other documents and material in the possession of the Court or the Registry that are not required by these Rules to be kept in the Court file.

Section.Text: The Administrator shall retain all files, annexes — other than the exhibits — and records that are required by these Rules to be kept for the period of time specified in the retention schedule established by the Court.

Subsection.Text: Where, in respect of an action, application or appeal that has not yet been commenced, a notice of motion for an extension of time, for leave to appeal or for any other order under a statute, rule or other enactment is filed, the notice of motion, any affidavits filed in respect thereof and any order made pursuant to the motion shall be kept in Court files maintained for notices of motion of that category.
If the proceeding is subsequently commenced, a copy of the order and of the other documents related to the motion shall be added to the Court file or annex for the proceeding, as applicable.

Section.MarginalNote: Transmitting paper copies filed at local office
Section.Text: When a document is filed in paper copy at a local office, the Administrator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: transmit that paper copy, without delay, to the principal office;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a certified copy of the document at the local office; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: transmit a copy of the document to any other local office where a copy is required for the business of the Court.

Subsection.Text: If the necessary facilities are available, a person may, with supervision and without interfering with the business of the Court, inspect a Court file or annex that is available to the public.
Nothing shall be removed or deleted from a Court file or annex except

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under an order of the Court;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by an officer of the Registry acting in the course of his or her duties; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with rule 26.1.

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise ordered by the Court, no Court file or annex to a Court file shall be removed from the Registry by any person other than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judge, prothonotary or referee; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an officer of the Registry acting in the course of his or her duties.

Subsection.Text: In this rule, appeal includes an appeal of an order of a prothonotary, an application for leave to appeal and an appeal to the Supreme Court of Canada.
Subject to subsection (4), exhibits put into evidence shall remain part of the annex to the Court file either

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: until the time for an appeal has expired, if no appeal has been taken, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: until the appeal is disposed of, if an appeal has been taken.

Subsection.Text: On the expiry of the time for appeal or on the disposition of the appeal, the Administrator shall return the exhibits to the respective solicitors or the parties who put the exhibits in evidence.

At any time following judgment, on requisition by the solicitor or party who put an exhibit in evidence or the person who produced it and on the filing of the consent of all parties, the Administrator shall return the exhibit to the person making the requisition.

If exhibits are not returnable to a party, solicitor or person or have not been claimed by a party, solicitor or person within one year after the expiry of the time for appeal or the disposition of the appeal referred to in subsection 26.1(3), the Administrator may seek directions from the Court as to their disposition.

The Court may, at the request of the Administrator, order that any exhibits not claimed by, or returnable to, a party, solicitor or other person be vested in Her Majesty in right of Canada or be destroyed.

Section.Text: The Court may sit at any time and at any place.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2) and rule 30, hearings of the Court, other than pre-trial or dispute resolution conferences, shall be open and accessible to the public.
On motion, the Court may direct that all or part of a proceeding be heard in camera if it is satisfied that the hearing should not be open to the public.
A judge or prothonotary who is not sitting in court may make an order on a motion if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the judge or prothonotary is satisfied that all parties affected have consented thereto;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the motion was brought in accordance with rule 369; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for any other reason the judge or prothonotary considers that the order can be made without a hearing without prejudice to any party.

Subsection.Text: On motion, the Court may set aside or vary an order made under paragraph (1)(a) on the ground that a party did not consent to it.

Section.Text: A request by a party under the Official Languages Act for an interpreter at a hearing shall be made in writing and be sent to the Administrator as soon as is practicable before the hearing begins.
The Court may order that a hearing be conducted in whole or in part by means of a telephone conference call, video-conference or any other form of electronic communication.

The Court may give directions to facilitate the conduct of a hearing by the use of any electronic or digital means of communication or storage or retrieval of information, or any other technology it considers appropriate.

Subsection.Text: General Sittings of the Federal Court for the hearing of motions shall be held, except during the Christmas or summer recess or on a holiday,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at Ottawa, every Wednesday and on any other day fixed by the Chief Justice of the Federal Court;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at Toronto and Vancouver, every Tuesday and on any other day fixed by the Chief Justice of the Federal Court;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in Quebec,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: at Montreal, every Tuesday and on any other day fixed by the Chief Justice of the Federal Court, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on a day and at any other place fixed by the Chief Justice of the Federal Court; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in every province other than Ontario, Quebec and British Columbia, at least once per month, on a day and at a place fixed by the Chief Justice of the Federal Court.

Subsection.Text: General Sittings may be cancelled by the Chief Justice of the Federal Court if no notice of a motion to be presented at the Sittings has been filed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in Ottawa, Montreal, Toronto or Vancouver, at least two days before the day of the Sittings; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other place, at least one week before the day of the Sittings.

Subsection.Text: General Sittings during the summer recess will be announced by the Chief Justice of the Federal Court before June 15 each year.
Subject to rule 298 and paragraph 385(1)(b), motions that can conveniently be heard at the General Sittings of the Federal Court may be made returnable accordingly.
A request may be made informally to the Judicial Administrator of the Federal Court of Appeal or the Federal Court, as the case may be, for an appointment of a special time and place

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for sittings of the Federal Court of Appeal or of a judge of that court to hear a motion; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for sittings of a judge of the Federal Court or of a prothonotary to hear a motion that is likely to be lengthy or a motion to be heard other than at General Sittings.

Subsection.Text: A hearing may be adjourned by the Court from time to time on such terms as the Court considers just.
Where a hearing is adjourned to a fixed day, a party who appeared at the hearing is deemed to have had notice of the adjournment.
Where a party has failed to appear at a hearing, that party need not be served with notice of an adjournment of the hearing.

Section.Text: Where at a hearing the Court considers that any person to whom notice of the hearing has not been given ought to have had such notice, the Court may adjourn the hearing or dismiss the proceeding or motion.

Where a party fails to appear at a hearing, the Court may proceed in the absence of the party if the Court is satisfied that notice of the hearing was given to that party in accordance with these Rules.

If a judge or referee of the Federal Court of Appeal or a Judge, prothonotary or referee of the Federal Court is for any reason unable to continue in a proceeding or to render a judgment that has been reserved, the Chief Justice of the court in question may order that the proceeding be reheard or retried, on any terms that the Chief Justice considers just.

Subsection.Text: On or before July 1 in each year, the Chief Justice of the Federal Court shall, in consultation with the other judges of that court, establish a rota of judges for Vancouver for the twelve months commencing on September 1 of that year, excluding the Christmas recess.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Powers of Chief Justice of the Federal Court
Subsection.Text: The Chief Justice of the Federal Court may make changes to the Vancouver rota, including the substitution of one judge for another during all or part of the judge's period of assignment.

A judge assigned to Vancouver shall reside in Vancouver for the period of the assignment and hold sittings and otherwise transact the judicial business of the Federal Court in Vancouver and in such other places as may be required.
Except with a judge's consent, the Chief Justice of the Federal Court shall not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: assign the judge to Vancouver for a period exceeding two months; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: reassign the judge to Vancouver for a second assignment within two months after the end of the first.

Heading.TitleText: Summoning of Witnesses or Other Persons

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), on receipt of a written request, the Administrator shall issue, in Form 41, a subpoena for the attendance of a witness or the production of a document or other material in a proceeding.
A subpoena may be issued in blank and completed by a solicitor or party.
Any number of names may be included in one subpoena.
No subpoena shall be issued without leave of the Court

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the production of an original record or of an original document, if the record or document may be proven by a copy in accordance with an Act of Parliament or of the legislature of a province;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to compel the appearance of a witness who resides more than 800 km from the place where the witness will be required to attend under the subpoena; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to compel the attendance of a witness at a hearing other than a trial or a reference under rule 153.

Subsection.Text: Leave may be granted under subsection (4) on an ex parte motion.

Section.Text: No witness is required to attend under a subpoena unless the subpoena has been personally served on the witness in accordance with paragraph 128(1)(a) and witness fees and travel expenses have been paid or tendered to the witness in the amount set out in Tariff A.
Where a witness is required under these Rules to attend a proceeding other than pursuant to a subpoena, the witness is entitled to witness fees and travel expenses in the amount set out in Tariff A.
On motion, the Court may make an order in Form 45 requiring that any person who is in the custody of a prison or penitentiary be brought before the Court.

Where a witness who is required to attend at a hearing fails to do so, on motion, the Court may, by a warrant in Form 46, order that the witness be apprehended anywhere in Canada, brought before the Court and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: detained in custody until the witness's presence is no longer required; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: released on a recognizance, with or without sureties, on condition that the witness attend to give evidence.

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise provided by these Rules, if these Rules grant a discretionary power to the Court, a judge or prothonotary has jurisdiction to exercise that power on his or her own initiative or on motion.
Where these Rules provide that powers of the Court are to be exercised on motion, they may be exercised only on the bringing of a motion.

Section.Text: If a proceeding has been commenced in the Federal Court of Appeal or the Federal Court, a judge of that court may order that the proceeding be transferred to the other court.

Subsection.Text: A prothonotary may hear, and make any necessary orders relating to, any motion under these Rules other than a motion

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of which these Rules or an Act of Parliament has expressly conferred jurisdiction on a judge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the Federal Court of Appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for summary judgment or summary trial other than

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in an action referred to in subsection (2), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of a claim referred to in subsection (3);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to hold a person in contempt at a hearing referred to in paragraph 467(1)(a);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: for an injunction;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: relating to the liberty of a person;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: to stay, set aside or vary an order of a judge, other than an order made under paragraph 385(a), (b) or (c);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: to stay execution of an order of a judge;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: to appoint a receiver;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: for an interim order under section 18.2 of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: to appeal the findings of a referee under rule 163; or

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: for the certification of an action or an application as a class proceeding.

Subsection.Text: A prothonotary may hear an action exclusively for monetary relief, or an action in rem claiming monetary relief, in which no amount claimed by a party exceeds $50,000 exclusive of interest and costs.

A prothonotary may hear a claim in respect of one or more individual questions in a class proceeding in which the amount claimed by a class member does not exceed $50,000 exclusive of interest and costs.
A prothonotary may hear an application under rule 327 for registration, recognition or enforcement of a foreign judgment.

Despite paragraphs (1)(c) and (k), a prothonotary may render any final judgment that could be rendered by a judge of the Federal Court, except in a proceeding in respect of which an Act of Parliament expressly confers jurisdiction on a judge, if the prothonotary is satisfied that all of the parties that will be affected by the judgment have given their consent.
An order of a prothonotary may be appealed by a motion to a judge of the Federal Court.
Notice of the motion shall be served and filed within 10 days after the day on which the order under appeal was made and at least four days before the day fixed for the hearing of the motion.
The Court may call on an assessor

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to assist the Court in understanding technical evidence; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to provide a written opinion in a proceeding.

Subsection.Text: An order made under subsection (1) shall provide for payment of the fees and disbursements of the assessor.
All communications between the Court and an assessor shall be in open court.
Before requesting a written opinion from an assessor, the Court shall allow the parties to make submissions in respect of the form and content of the question to be asked.
Before judgment is rendered, the Court shall provide the parties with the questions asked of, and any opinion given by, an assessor and give them an opportunity to make submissions thereon.
A party to a proceeding may name an expert witness whether or not an assessor has been called on under rule 52.
Two or more of the parties may jointly name an expert witness.
An affidavit or statement of an expert witness shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out in full the proposed evidence of the expert;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set out the expert’s qualifications and the areas in respect of which it is proposed that he or she be qualified as an expert;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be accompanied by a certificate in Form 52.2 signed by the expert acknowledging that the expert has read the Code of Conduct for Expert Witnesses set out in the schedule and agrees to be bound by it; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a statement, be in writing, signed by the expert and accompanied by a solicitor’s certificate.

Subsection.Text: If an expert fails to comply with the Code of Conduct for Expert Witnesses, the Court may exclude some or all of the expert’s affidavit or statement.

Section.Text: The rules governing expert witnesses do not apply to a medical professional who has given or is giving medical treatment or advice to a person if the evidence in relation to the person is limited to one or more of the following subjects:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the results of an examination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the treatment or advice;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the reason the treatment or advice was or is being given; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the results of the treatment or advice.

Subsection.Text: A party intending to call more than five expert witnesses in a proceeding shall seek leave of the Court in accordance with section 7 of the Canada Evidence Act.
In deciding whether to grant leave, the Court shall consider all relevant matters, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the litigation, its public significance and any need to clarify the law;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number, complexity or technical nature of the issues in dispute; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the likely expense involved in calling the expert witnesses in relation to the amount in dispute in the proceeding.

Subsection.Text: A party to a proceeding shall, as early as possible in the proceeding, raise any objection to an opposing party’s proposed expert witness that could disqualify the witness from testifying.
An objection may be raised

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by serving and filing a document containing the particulars of and basis for the objection; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with subsection 262(2) or subparagraph 263(c)(i) if, in the case of an action, the objection is known prior to the pre-trial conference.

Subsection.Text: The Court may order expert witnesses to confer with one another in advance of the hearing of the proceeding in order to narrow the issues and identify the points on which their views differ.
Subsection (1) does not preclude the parties and their counsel from attending an expert conference but the conference may take place in their absence if the parties agree.
The Court may order that an expert conference take place in the presence of a judge or prothonotary.

A joint statement prepared by the expert witnesses following an expert conference is admissible at the hearing of the proceeding . Discussions in an expert conference and documents prepared for the purposes of a conference are confidential and shall not be disclosed to the judge or prothonotary presiding at the hearing of the proceeding unless the parties consent.
In making an order under these Rules, the Court may impose such conditions and give such directions as it considers just.
Where these Rules provide that the Court may make an order of a specified nature, the Court may make any other order that it considers just.

Section.Text: A person may at any time bring a motion for directions concerning the procedure to be followed under these Rules.

Heading.TitleText: Varying Rules and Dispensing with Compliance

Section.MarginalNote: Varying rule and dispensing with compliance
Section.Text: In special circumstances, in a proceeding, the Court may vary a rule or dispense with compliance with a rule.
Non-compliance with any of these Rules does not render a proceeding, a step in a proceeding or an order void, but instead constitutes an irregularity, which may be addressed under rules 58 to 60.
An originating document shall not be set aside only on the ground that a different originating document should have been used.

Subsection.Text: A party may by motion challenge any step taken by another party for non-compliance with these Rules.
A motion under subsection (1) shall be brought as soon as practicable after the moving party obtains knowledge of the irregularity.

Section.Text: Subject to rule 57, where, on a motion brought under rule 58, the Court finds that a party has not complied with these Rules, the Court may, by order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: dismiss the motion, where the motion was not brought within a sufficient time after the moving party became aware of the irregularity to avoid prejudice to the respondent in the motion;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: grant any amendments required to address the irregularity; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set aside the proceeding, in whole or in part.

Section.MarginalNote: Non-compliance with Rules or gap in case
Section.Text: At any time before judgment is given in a proceeding, the Court may draw the attention of a party to any gap in the proof of its case or to any non-compliance with these Rules and permit the party to remedy it on such conditions as the Court considers just.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), a proceeding referred to in rule 169 shall be brought as an action.
Subject to subsection (4), a proceeding referred to in rule 300 shall be brought as an application.
A proceeding referred to in rule 335 shall be brought as an appeal.

Where by or under an Act of Parliament a person is given the option of bringing a proceeding referred to in rule 169 or 300 as either an action or an application, the person may commence the proceeding as an action or as an application.
Subject to subsection (2), all actions, applications or appeals shall be commenced by the issuance of an originating document.

A counterclaim or third party claim in an action brought only against persons who are already parties to the action shall be commenced by the service and filing of the counterclaim or third party claim.
Unless otherwise provided by or under an Act of Parliament, the originating document for the commencement of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an action, including an appeal by way of an action, is a statement of claim;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a counterclaim against a person who is not yet a party to the action is a statement of defence and counterclaim;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a third party claim against a person who is not yet a party to the action is a third party claim;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an application is a notice of application; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an appeal is a notice of appeal.

Subsection.Text: Where by or under an Act of Parliament a proceeding is to be commenced by way of a document different from the originating document required under these Rules, the rules applicable to the originating document apply in respect of that document.

Section.Text: No proceeding is subject to challenge on the ground that only a declaratory order is sought, and the Court may make a binding declaration of right in a proceeding whether or not any consequential relief is or can be claimed.

A printed document that is prepared for use in a proceeding shall be legible, the print — including all references in the document — shall be in 12-point Times New Roman, Arial or Tahoma font and each page of the document shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be on good quality white or off-white paper, measuring 21.5 cm by 28 cm (8½ in. by 11 in.);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have top and bottom margins of not less than 2.5 cm and left and right margins of not less than 3.5 cm;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be printed on one side of the paper only, unless the document is a book of authorities; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: have no more than 30 lines, exclusive of headings.

Subsection.Text: The first page of a document prepared for use in a proceeding shall have a heading in Form 66 that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the court and the Court file number; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the style of cause in accordance with rule 67.

Subsection.Text: A document prepared for use in a proceeding shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the title of the document;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number and fax number of the solicitor filing the document or, where a party is not represented by a solicitor, the party's name, an address for service in Canada, a telephone number and any fax number; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if there is consent to the electronic service of documents, the electronic address set out in Form 141A.

Subsection.Text: A document prepared for use in a proceeding shall be signed by the solicitor or party filing it.

Section.MarginalNote: Style of cause in originating document

Subsection.Text: An originating document shall contain a style of cause that sets out the names of all parties and the capacity of any party that is not acting in its personal capacity.
The style of cause in an action shall name each party commencing the action as a plaintiff and each adverse party as a defendant.

The style of cause in an application shall name each party commencing the application as an applicant and each adverse party as a respondent and state any legislative provision or rule under which the application is made.
The style of cause in an appeal shall name each party bringing the appeal as an appellant and each adverse party as a respondent.

In a document other than an originating document or order, where there are more than two parties to the proceeding, a short style of cause may be used, showing the names of the first party on each side followed by the expression "and others".

Subsection.MarginalNote: Motions prior to commencement of proceeding
Subsection.Text: Subsections (1) to (4) apply, with such modifications as are required, to a motion brought prior to the commencement of an action, application or appeal.

Subject to subsection (2), all documents required under these Rules to be filed in a proceeding shall be in English or French or be accompanied by a translation in English or French and an affidavit attesting to the accuracy of the translation.
All pleadings, memoranda of fact and law and written representations on motions shall be in English or French.

Section.Text: A notice of a constitutional question referred to in section 57 of the Act shall be in Form 69.

Subsection.Text: A memorandum of fact and law shall contain, in consecutively numbered paragraphs,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a concise statement of fact, as Part I of the memorandum;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the points in issue, as Part II of the memorandum;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a concise statement of submissions, as Part III of the memorandum;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a concise statement of the order sought, including any order concerning costs, as Part IV of the memorandum;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the authorities to be referred to, as Part V of the memorandum;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in a proceeding other than an appeal, the provisions of any statutes or regulations cited or relied on that have not been reproduced in another party's memorandum, as Appendix A to the memorandum; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in a proceeding other than an appeal, a book of the authorities to be referred to that have not been included in another party's book of authorities, as Appendix B to the memorandum.

Subsection.Text: Extracts of federal statutes and regulations in Appendix A to a memorandum of fact and law shall be reproduced in both official languages.
If a memorandum of fact and law is filed in paper copy, the appendices may be bound separately from the memorandum.
Unless otherwise ordered by the Court, a memorandum of fact and law, exclusive of Part V and appendices, shall not exceed 30 pages in length.
A document may be sent to the Registry for the purpose of filing by delivery, mail, fax or electronic transmission.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Sending by fax — prior consent required
Subsection.Text: The Administrator’s consent is required before any of the following documents may be sent by fax:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a motion record, application record, trial record, appeal book or book of authorities; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other document that is longer than 20 pages.

Subsection.Text: A document that is sent by fax shall include a cover page that sets out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address and telephone number of the sender;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date and time of the transmission;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the total number of pages being transmitted, including the cover page;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a fax number at which the sender may receive documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name and telephone number of the person that is to be contacted in the event of a transmission problem.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Sending by electronic transmission — document format
Subsection.Text: A document that is sent by electronic transmission shall be in PDF (Portable Document Format) or any other format that is approved by the Court.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Originating documents sent by electronic transmission
Subsection.Text: A person who sends an originating document by electronic transmission shall provide the Registry with paper copies for issuance or arrange for the Registry to prepare those copies.
A document that was sent to the Registry in accordance with rule 71 is submitted for filing when

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is received and dated by the Registry; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a fee for its issuance or filing is payable under Tariff A, the fee is paid.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a document that was sent by electronic transmission to the Registry for filing, the time of its receipt by the Registry is that time in the Eastern time zone.
A document that is submitted for filing on a holiday is deemed to have been submitted for filing on the next day that is not a holiday.
Where a document is submitted for filing, the Administrator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: accept the document for filing; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the Administrator is of the opinion that the document is not in the form required by these Rules or that other conditions precedent to its filing have not been fulfilled, refer the document without delay to a judge or prothonotary.

Subsection.Text: On receipt of a document referred under paragraph (1)(b), the judge or prothonotary may direct the Administrator to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: accept or reject the document; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: accept the document subject to conditions as to the making of any corrections or the fulfilling of any conditions precedent.

Section.Text: Unless the Court directs otherwise, a document that is accepted for filing is deemed to have been filed at the time the document was submitted for filing.

Section.MarginalNote: Paper copies — fax or electronic transmission
Section.Text: A person who files a document by fax or electronic transmission shall, if required by the Court, provide the Registry with the same number of paper copies of the document as would have been required had the document been filed in paper copy.

Section.MarginalNote: Retention and provision of paper copy
Section.Text: A person who, by electronic transmission, files a document that is originally in paper copy and that bears a signature shall retain the paper copy of the document for the duration of any appeal and for 30 days after the expiry of all appeal periods and, if required by the Court, provide that paper copy to the Registry.
No document required to be served, other than an originating document, shall be filed without proof that it has been served within the time and in the manner provided for by these Rules.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the Court may, at any time, order that a document that is not filed in accordance with these Rules or pursuant to an order of the Court or an Act of Parliament be removed from the Court file.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Opportunity for interested parties to be heard
Subsection.Text: An order may be made of the Court's own initiative under subsection (1) only if all interested parties have been given an opportunity to be heard.
Subject to subsection (2) and rule 76, the Court may, on motion, at any time, allow a party to amend a document, on such terms as will protect the rights of all parties.
No amendment shall be allowed under subsection (1) during or after a hearing unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the purpose is to make the document accord with the issues at the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a new hearing is ordered; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the other parties are given an opportunity for any preparation necessary to meet any new or amended allegations.

Section.Text: With leave of the Court, an amendment may be made

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to correct the name of a party, if the Court is satisfied that the mistake sought to be corrected was not such as to cause a reasonable doubt as to the identity of the party, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to alter the capacity in which a party is bringing a proceeding, if the party could have commenced the proceeding in its altered capacity at the date of commencement of the proceeding,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: unless to do so would result in prejudice to a party that would not be compensable by costs or an adjournment.

Section.MarginalNote: Amendment after expiration of limitation period
Section.Text: The Court may allow an amendment under rule 76 notwithstanding the expiration of a relevant period of limitation that had not expired at the date of commencement of the proceeding.

Unless the Court orders otherwise, where these Rules provide for doing an act or taking a step in a proceeding within a prescribed period after the service or filing of a document and that document is subsequently amended in accordance with these Rules, the period shall be calculated from the day of service or filing of the amended document, as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: A filed document may be amended

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the amendment does not require the insertion of more than 10 words in any one page, by writing the amendment on the document, serving a copy of the amended document on all other parties and filing proof of service thereof; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, by serving and filing an amended document in which the amendments are underlined.

Subsection.Text: An amendment made under subsection (1) shall indicate the rule or Court order under which the amendment is made.
Affidavits shall be drawn in the first person, in Form 80A.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Affidavit by blind or illiterate person
Subsection.Text: Where an affidavit is made by a deponent who is blind or illiterate, the person before whom the affidavit is sworn shall certify that the affidavit was read to the deponent and that the deponent appeared to understand it.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Affidavit by deponent who does not understand an official language
Subsection.Text: Where an affidavit is written in an official language for a deponent who does not understand that official language, the affidavit shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be translated orally for the deponent in the language of the deponent by a competent and independent interpreter who has taken an oath, in Form 80B, as to the performance of his or her duties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: contain a jurat in Form 80C.

Subsection.Text: Where an affidavit refers to an exhibit, the exhibit shall be accurately identified by an endorsement on the exhibit or on a certificate attached to it, signed by the person before whom the affidavit is sworn.

Affidavits shall be confined to facts within the deponent’s personal knowledge except on motions, other than motions for summary judgment or summary trial, in which statements as to the deponent’s belief, with the grounds for it, may be included.
Where an affidavit is made on belief, an adverse inference may be drawn from the failure of a party to provide evidence of persons having personal knowledge of material facts.

Section.Text: Except with leave of the Court, a solicitor shall not both depose to an affidavit and present argument to the Court based on that affidavit.
A party to a motion or application may cross-examine the deponent of an affidavit served by an adverse party to the motion or application.

Subsection.Text: A party seeking to cross-examine the deponent of an affidavit filed in a motion or application shall not do so until the party has served on all other parties every affidavit on which the party intends to rely in the motion or application, except with the consent of all other parties or with leave of the Court.

A party who has cross-examined the deponent of an affidavit filed in a motion or application may not subsequently file an affidavit in that motion or application, except with the consent of all other parties or with leave of the Court.

Section.Text: A party who intends to cross-examine the deponent of an affidavit shall do so with due diligence.
Unless the Court orders otherwise, a party who conducts a cross-examination on an affidavit shall order and pay for a transcript thereof and send a copy to each other party.
In rules 88 to 100, examination means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an examination for discovery;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the taking of evidence out of court for use at trial;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a cross-examination on an affidavit; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an examination in aid of execution.

Subsection.Text: Subject to rules 234 and 296, an examination may be conducted orally or in writing.
The Court may order that an examination out of court be recorded by video recording or conducted by video-conference or any other form of electronic communication.
A party requesting an oral examination shall pay the fees and disbursements related to recording the examination in accordance with Tariff A.
An oral examination that takes place in Canada shall be recorded by a person authorized to record examinations for discovery under the practice and procedure of a superior court in Canada.
An oral examination that takes place in a jurisdiction outside Canada shall be recorded by a person authorized to record

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: court proceedings in that jurisdiction; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: examinations for discovery under the practice and procedure of a superior court in Canada, if the parties consent.

Subsection.Text: A person who records an oral examination shall record it word for word, including any comment made by a solicitor, other than statements that the attending parties agree to exclude from the record.

Where a person to be examined on an oral examination resides in Canada and the person and the parties cannot agree on where to conduct the oral examination, it shall be conducted in the place closest to the person's residence where a superior court sits.

Where a person to be examined on an oral examination resides outside Canada, the time, place, manner and expenses of the oral examination shall be as agreed on by the person and the parties or, on motion, as ordered by the Court.
No person is required to attend an oral examination unless reasonable travel expenses have been paid or tendered to the person.
A party who intends to conduct an oral examination shall serve a direction to attend, in Form 91, on the person to be examined and a copy thereof on every other party.
A direction to attend may direct the person to be examined to produce for inspection at the examination

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an examination for discovery, all documents and other material in the possession, power or control of the party on behalf of whom the person is being examined that are relevant to the matters in issue in the action;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of the taking of evidence for use at trial, all documents and other material in that person's possession, power or control that are relevant to the matters in issue in the action;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a cross-examination on an affidavit, all documents and other material in that person's possession, power or control that are relevant to the application or motion; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an examination in aid of execution, all documents and other material in that person's possession, power or control that are relevant to the person's ability to satisfy the judgment.

Subsection.Text: A direction to attend an oral examination shall be served

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the person to be examined is an adverse party, at least six days before the day of the proposed examination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the person to be examined is not a party to the proceeding, at least 10 days before the day of the proposed examination; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the person is to be cross-examined on an affidavit filed in support of a motion, at least 24 hours before the hearing of the motion.

Section.Text: A person to be examined on an oral examination shall be sworn before being examined.

Subsection.Text: Where a person to be examined on an oral examination understands neither French nor English or is deaf or mute, the examining party shall arrange for the attendance and pay the fees and disbursements of an independent and competent person to accurately interpret everything said during the examination, other than statements that the attending parties agree to exclude from the record.

Where an interpreter is required because the examining party wishes to conduct an oral examination in one official language and the person to be examined wishes to be examined in the other official language, on the request of the examining party made at least six days before the examination, the Administrator shall arrange for the attendance and pay the fees and disbursements of an independent and competent interpreter.
Before aiding in the examination of a witness, an interpreter shall take an oath, in Form 93, as to the performance of his or her duties.

Subject to subsection (2), a person who is to be examined on an oral examination or the party on whose behalf that person is being examined shall produce for inspection at the examination all documents and other material requested in the direction to attend that are within that person's or party's possession and control, other than any documents for which privilege has been claimed or for which relief from production has been granted under rule 230.

On motion, the Court may order that a person to be examined or the party on whose behalf that person is being examined be relieved from the requirement to produce for inspection any document or other material requested in a direction to attend, if the Court is of the opinion that the document or other material requested is irrelevant or, by reason of its nature or the number of documents or amount of material requested, it would be unduly onerous to require the person or party to produce it.
A person who objects to a question that is asked in an oral examination shall briefly state the grounds for the objection for the record.
A person may answer a question that was objected to in an oral examination subject to the right to have the propriety of the question determined, on motion, before the answer is used at trial.

A person being examined may adjourn an oral examination and bring a motion for directions if the person believes that he or she is being subjected to an excessive number of questions or to improper questions, or that the examination is being conducted in bad faith or in an abusive manner.

A person conducting an oral examination may adjourn the examination and bring a motion for directions if the person believes answers to questions being provided are evasive or if the person being examined fails to produce a document or other material requested under rule 94.
On a motion under subsection (1) or (2), the Court may sanction, through costs, a person whose conduct necessitated the motion or a person who unnecessarily adjourned the examination.

Section.Text: Where a person fails to attend an oral examination or refuses to take an oath, answer a proper question, produce a document or other material required to be produced or comply with an order made under rule 96, the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: order the person to attend or re-attend, as the case may be, at his or her own expense;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: order the person to answer a question that was improperly objected to and any proper question arising from the answer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: strike all or part of the person's evidence, including an affidavit made by the person;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: dismiss the proceeding or give judgment by default, as the case may be; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: order the person or the party on whose behalf the person is being examined to pay the costs of the examination.

Section.Text: A person who does not comply with an order made under rule 96 or 97 may be found in contempt.

Subsection.Text: A party who intends to examine a person by way of a written examination shall serve a list of concise, separately numbered questions in Form 99A for the person to answer.
A person who objects to a question in a written examination may bring a motion to have the question struck out.
A person examined by way of a written examination shall answer by way of an affidavit.
An affidavit referred to in subsection (3) shall be in Form 99B and be served on every other party within 30 days after service of the written examination under subsection (1).

Section.Text: Rules 94, 95, 97 and 98 apply to written examinations, with such modifications as are necessary.

Subsection.Text: Subject to rule 302, a party to a proceeding may request relief against another party to the same proceeding in respect of more than one claim.
A party may request relief in a separate capacity in respect of different claims in a single proceeding.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Interest in all relief not essential
Subsection.Text: Not all parties to a proceeding need have an interest in all relief claimed in the proceeding.

Section.Text: Two or more persons who are represented by the same solicitor may join in one proceeding as plaintiffs, applicants or appellants where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if separate proceedings were brought by each of them, a common question of law or fact would arise in all of the proceedings; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the relief claimed, whether joint, several or alternative, arises from substantially the same facts or matter.

Subsection.Text: No proceeding shall be defeated by reason of the misjoinder or nonjoinder of a person or party.

In a proceeding in which a proper person or party has not been joined, the Court shall determine the issues in dispute so far as they affect the rights and interests of the persons who are parties to the proceeding.

Section.MarginalNote: Order for joinder or relief against joinder

Subsection.Text: At any time, the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: order that a person who is not a proper or necessary party shall cease to be a party; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: order that a person who ought to have been joined as a party or whose presence before the Court is necessary to ensure that all matters in dispute in the proceeding may be effectually and completely determined be added as a party, but no person shall be added as a plaintiff or applicant without his or her consent, signified in writing or in such other manner as the Court may order.

Subsection.Text: An order made under subsection (1) shall contain directions as to amendment of the originating document and any other pleadings.

Section.Text: The Court may order, in respect of two or more proceedings,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that they be consolidated, heard together or heard one immediately after the other;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that one proceeding be stayed until another proceeding is determined; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that one of the proceedings be asserted as a counterclaim or cross-appeal in another proceeding.

Section.MarginalNote: Separate determination of claims and issues
Section.Text: Where the hearing of two or more claims or parties in a single proceeding would cause undue complication or delay or would prejudice a party, the Court may order that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: claims against one or more parties be pursued separately;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one or more claims be pursued separately;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a party be compensated for, or relieved from, attending any part of the proceeding in which the party does not have an interest; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the proceeding against a party be stayed on condition that the party is bound by any findings against another party.

Subsection.Text: The Court may, at any time, order the trial of an issue or that issues in a proceeding be determined separately.
In an order under subsection (1), the Court may give directions regarding the procedures to be followed, including those applicable to examinations for discovery and the discovery of documents.
Where two or more persons make conflicting claims against another person in respect of property in the possession of that person and that person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: claims no interest in the property, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is willing to deposit the property with the Court or dispose of it as the Court directs,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: that person may bring an ex parte motion for directions as to how the claims are to be decided.

Subsection.Text: On a motion under subsection (1), the Court shall give directions regarding

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notice to be given to possible claimants and advertising for claimants;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the time within which claimants shall be required to file their claims; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the procedure to be followed in determining the rights of the claimants.

Subsection.Text: The Court may, on motion, grant leave to any person to intervene in a proceeding.
Notice of a motion under subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out the full name and address of the proposed intervener and of any solicitor acting for the proposed intervener; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: describe how the proposed intervener wishes to participate in the proceeding and how that participation will assist the determination of a factual or legal issue related to the proceeding.

Subsection.Text: In granting a motion under subsection (1), the Court shall give directions regarding

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the service of documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the role of the intervener, including costs, rights of appeal and any other matters relating to the procedure to be followed by the intervener.

Section.Text: Where a question of general importance is raised in a proceeding, other than a question referred to in section 57 of the Act,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any party may serve notice of the question on the Attorney General of Canada and any attorney general of a province who may be interested;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Court may direct the Administrator to bring the proceeding to the attention of the Attorney General of Canada and any attorney general of a province who may be interested; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Attorney General of Canada and the attorney general of a province may apply for leave to intervene.

Section.Text: A proceeding may be brought by or against an unincorporated association in the name of the association.
A proceeding by or against two or more persons as partners may be brought in the name of the partnership.
A proceeding by or against a person carrying on business as a sole proprietor may be brought in the name of the sole proprietorship.

Subsection.Text: A proceeding may be brought by or against the trustees, executors or administrators of an estate or trust without joining the beneficiaries of the estate or trust.
Unless the Court orders otherwise, beneficiaries of an estate or trust are bound by an order against the estate or trust.

Where a party to a proceeding is deceased and the estate of the deceased is not represented, the Court may appoint a person to represent the estate of the deceased or order that the proceeding continue without representation of the estate.
Before making an order under subsection (1), the Court may require that notice be given to all persons who have an interest in the estate of the deceased.

Despite rule 302, a proceeding, other than a proceeding referred to in section 27 or 28 of the Act, may be brought by or against a person acting as a representative on behalf of one or more other persons on the condition that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the issues asserted by or against the representative and the represented persons

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are common issues of law and fact and there are no issues affecting only some of those persons, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: relate to a collective interest shared by those persons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the representative is authorized to act on behalf of the represented persons;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the representative can fairly and adequately represent the interests of the represented persons; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the use of a representative proceeding is the just, most efficient and least costly manner of proceeding.

Subsection.Text: At any time, the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine whether the conditions set out in subsection (1) are being satisfied;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: require that notice be given, in a form and manner directed by it, to the represented persons;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: impose any conditions on the settlement process of a representative proceeding that the Court considers appropriate; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide for the replacement of the representative if that person is unable to represent the interests of the represented persons fairly and adequately.

Subsection.Text: An order in a representative proceeding is binding on the represented persons unless otherwise ordered by the Court.
The discontinuance or settlement of a representative proceeding is not effective unless it is approved by the Court.
Every document in a proceeding commenced under subsection (1) shall be prefaced by the heading “Representative Proceeding”.
The Court may appoint one or more persons to represent

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: unborn or unascertained persons who may have a present, future, contingent or other interest in a proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person under a legal disability against or by whom a proceeding is brought.

Subsection.Text: The Court may appoint as a representative under subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who has already been appointed as such a representative under the laws of a province; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person eligible to act as a representative in the jurisdiction in which the person to be represented is domiciled.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, a person for whom a representative is appointed under subsection (1) is bound by any order made in the proceeding.

Section.Text: A proceeding is not terminated only by reason that a party to a proceeding dies or becomes bankrupt or, in the case of a corporation, ceases to exist.

Section.MarginalNote: Assignment, transmission or devolution of interest or liability

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), where an interest of a party in, or the liability of a party under, a proceeding is assigned or transmitted to, or devolves upon, another person, the other person may, after serving and filing a notice and affidavit setting out the basis for the assignment, transmission or devolution, carry on the proceeding.

If a party to a proceeding objects to its continuance by a person referred to in subsection (1), the person seeking to continue the proceeding shall bring a motion for an order to be substituted for the original party.
In an order given under subsection (2), the Court may give directions as to the further conduct of the proceeding.

Section.Text: Where an interest of a party in, or the liability of a party under, a proceeding has been assigned or transmitted to, or devolves upon, a person and that person has not, within 30 days, served a notice and affidavit referred to in subsection 117(1) or obtained an order under subsection 117(2), any other party to the proceeding may bring a motion for default judgment or to have the proceeding dismissed.
Subject to rule 121, an individual may act in person or be represented by a solicitor in a proceeding.

A corporation, partnership or unincorporated association shall be represented by a solicitor in all proceedings, unless the Court in special circumstances grants leave to it to be represented by an officer, partner or member, as the case may be.

Section.MarginalNote: Parties under legal disability or acting in representative capacity
Section.Text: Unless the Court in special circumstances orders otherwise, a party who is under a legal disability or who acts or seeks to act in a representative capacity, including in a representative proceeding or a class proceeding, shall be represented by a solicitor.

Section.MarginalNote: Rights and obligations of party acting in person
Section.Text: Subject to paragraphs 152(2)(a) and 146(1)(b), unless the Court orders otherwise, a party not represented by a solicitor or a person authorized under rule 120 to represent a party shall do everything required, and may do anything permitted, to be done by a solicitor under these Rules.
Where a party takes a step in a proceeding by filing or serving a document signed by a solicitor, that solicitor is the solicitor of record for the party.

Section.MarginalNote: Notice of change or removal of solicitor
Section.Text: A party may change or remove its solicitor of record or appoint a solicitor of record by serving and filing a notice in Form 124A, 124B or 124C, as the case may be.

Section.MarginalNote: Motion for removal of solicitor of record

Subsection.Text: Where a solicitor of record ceases to act for a party and the party has not changed its solicitor of record in accordance with rule 124, the Court may, on a motion of the solicitor, order that the solicitor be removed from the record.
A notice of motion under subsection (1) shall be served on the party formerly represented by the solicitor

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by personal service; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where personal service cannot practicably be effected,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by mailing the notice of motion to the party at the party's last known address, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if no mailing address of the party is known, by depositing the notice of motion at the Registry office where the proceeding was initiated.

Subsection.Text: An order made under subsection (1) removing a solicitor of record of a party shall be served on the party in the manner set out in subsection (2) and on all other parties to the proceeding.
An order under subsection (1) does not take effect until proof of its service has been filed.

Section.MarginalNote: Solicitor of record ceasing to act
Section.Text: A party is deemed not to be represented by a solicitor if the party does not appoint a new solicitor after its solicitor of record

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: dies; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ceases to act for the party because of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: appointment to a public office incompatible with the solicitor's profession,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: suspension or disbarment as a solicitor, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an order made under rule 125.

Subsection.Text: An originating document that has been issued, other than in an appeal from the Federal Court to the Federal Court of Appeal or an ex parte application under rule 327, shall be served personally.
A party who has already participated in the proceeding need not be personally served.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Service of notice of appeal on the Crown
Subsection.Text: Despite subsections (1) and (2), in the case of an appeal from Federal Court to the Federal Court of Appeal, if the Crown, the Attorney General of Canada or any other minister of the Crown is a respondent, the notice of appeal shall be served personally on them in accordance with rule 133.
Personal service of a document on an individual, other than an individual under a legal disability, is effected

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by leaving the document with the individual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by leaving the document with an adult person residing at the individual's place of residence, and mailing a copy of the document to the individual at that address;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the individual is carrying on a business in Canada, other than a partnership, in a name or style other than the individual's own name, by leaving the document with the person apparently having control or management of the business at any place where the business is carried on in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: by mailing the document to the individual's last known address, accompanied by an acknowledgement of receipt form in Form 128, if the individual signs and returns the acknowledgement of receipt card or signs a post office receipt;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: by mailing the document by registered mail to the individual's last known address, if the individual signs a post office receipt; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in any other manner provided by an Act of Parliament applicable to the proceeding.

Subsection.Text: Service under paragraph (1)(b) is effective on the tenth day after the copy is mailed.
Service under paragraph (1)(d) or (e) is effective on the day of receipt indicated on the acknowledgement of receipt form or post office receipt, as the case may be.

Section.MarginalNote: Personal service on individual under legal disability
Section.Text: Personal service of a document on an individual under a legal disability is effected by serving the individual in such a manner as the Court may order, having regard to the manner in which the interests of the person will be best protected.
