Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), personal service of a document on a corporation is effected

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by leaving the document

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: with an officer or director of the corporation or a person employed by the corporation as legal counsel, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: with the person apparently in charge, at the time of the service, of the head office or of the branch or agency in Canada where the service is effected;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the manner provided by any Act of Parliament applicable to the proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the manner provided for service on a corporation in proceedings before a superior court in the province in which the service is being effected.

Subsection.Text: Personal service of a document on a municipal corporation is effected by leaving the document with the chief executive officer or legal counsel of the municipality.

Section.Text: Personal service of a document on a partnership is effected by leaving the document with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the partnership is a limited partnership, a general partner; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, a partner or the person who has the control or management of the partnership business at its principal place of business in Canada.

Section.Text: Personal service of a document on a sole proprietorship is effected by leaving the document with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sole proprietor; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person apparently in charge, at the time of the service, of the place of business of the sole proprietorship in Canada where the service is effected.

Section.Text: Personal service of a document on an unincorporated association is effected by leaving the document with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an officer of the association; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person who has the control or management of the affairs of the association at any office or premises occupied by the association.

Section.MarginalNote: Personal service of originating document on the Crown

Subsection.Text: Personal service of an originating document on the Crown, the Attorney General of Canada or any other Minister of the Crown is effected by filing the original and two paper copies of it at the Registry.
The Administrator shall forthwith transmit a certified copy of an originating document filed under subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where it was filed at the principal office of the Registry, to the office of the Deputy Attorney General of Canada in Ottawa; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where it was filed at a local office, to the Director of the regional office of the Department of Justice referred to in subsection 4(2) of the Crown Liability and Proceedings (Provincial Court) Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Service under subsection (1) is effective at the time the document is filed.

Section.Text: Personal service of a document on a party may be effected by the acceptance of service by the party's solicitor.

Section.MarginalNote: Deemed personal service on a person outside Canada
Section.Text: Where a person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is resident outside Canada and, in the ordinary course of business, enters into contracts or business transactions in Canada in connection with which the person regularly makes use of the services of a person resident in Canada, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: made use of such services in connection with a contract or business transaction,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: in a proceeding arising out of the contract or transaction, personal service of a document on the person resident outside Canada is effected by personally serving the person resident in Canada.

Section.MarginalNote: Substituted service or dispensing with service

Subsection.Text: Where service of a document that is required to be served personally cannot practicably be effected, the Court may order substitutional service or dispense with service.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Motion may be made ex parte
Subsection.Text: A motion for an order under subsection (1) may be made ex parte.
A document served by substitutional service shall make reference to the order that authorized the substitutional service.

Subject to subsection (2), a document to be personally served outside Canada may be served in the manner set out in rules 127 to 136 or in the manner prescribed by the law of the jurisdiction in which service is to be effected.
Where service is to be effected in a contracting state to the Hague Convention, service shall be as provided by the Convention.
Service of documents outside Canada may be proven

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the manner set out in rule 146;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the manner provided by the law of the jurisdiction in which service was effected; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the Hague Convention, if service is effected in a contracting state.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise provided in these Rules, personal service is required only for originating documents.

Subsection.Text: If a document is not required to be served personally, service on a party is to be effected by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: personal service;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: leaving it at the party’s address for service;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: mailing it or delivering it by courier to the party’s address for service;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: transmitting it by fax to the party’s solicitor of record, or, if the party has no solicitor of record, to the party;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: transmitting it to the electronic address set out by the party in Form 141A; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any other means that the Court may direct.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection 36(3) and rule 145, the document shall be served on all other parties.
If a party has no address for service at the time of service, the document may be served by leaving it at, or by sending it by registered mail or courier to,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the party is an individual, the party’s usual or last known address; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the party is an unincorporated body, a group of persons or a corporation, the principal or last known address of the body, group or corporation.

Subsection.Text: If a party has no known address at the time of service, the document may be served by depositing it at the office of the Registry where the proceeding was commenced.
The recipient’s consent is required before any of the following documents may be served by fax:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a motion record, application record, trial record, appeal book or book of authorities; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other document that is longer than 20 pages.

Subsection.Text: A document that is served by fax shall include a cover page that sets out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address and telephone number of the sender;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person on whom the document is being served;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date and time of the transmission;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the total number of pages being transmitted, including the cover page;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a fax number at which the sender may receive documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name and telephone number of the person that is to be contacted in the event of a transmission problem.

Subsection.Text: A party consents to the electronic service of documents by serving and filing a notice of consent in Form 141A.
The consent is effective on the day on which the notice is served.
A party withdraws their consent by serving and filing a notice of withdrawal of consent in Form 141B.
The withdrawal of consent is effective on the day on which the notice is served.
A party shall not serve a document by electronic service prior to being served with the recipient’s notice of consent or after the withdrawal of that consent.

Section.Text: Service of a document under these Rules may be effected at any time.

Section.MarginalNote: Effective date — evening or holiday service

Subsection.Text: Service of a document, other than an originating document or a warrant, on a holiday or after 5:00 p.m. at the recipient’s local time is effective on the next day that is not a holiday.
Service of a document by ordinary mail is effective on the 10th day after the day on which it is mailed.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Effective date — registered mail or courier
Subsection.Text: Service of a document by registered mail or courier is effective on the day of delivery that is indicated on the post office or courier delivery receipt, as the case may be.

Section.Text: A document that is served by ordinary mail may be filed before the day on which its service is effective.

Subject to subsection 207(2) or unless the Court orders otherwise, a party who has been served with an originating document is not required to be served with any further documents in the proceeding prior to final judgment if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the party has not filed a notice of appearance or a defence within the time set out in these Rules; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the party has no address for service and has not served and filed a notice of consent to electronic service in Form 141A.

Subsection.Text: Service of a document is proven by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an affidavit of service in Form 146A or, if the service is effected in the Province of Quebec, a certificate of service of a sheriff, bailiff or other authorized person in accordance with the Code of Civil Procedure of that Province;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the document is not an originating document, a solicitor’s certificate of service in Form 146B;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the service is effected by leaving a copy of the document at a solicitor‘s office, by an acknowledgement of service that is signed and dated by the solicitor or another person on behalf of the solicitor; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the service is effected under rule 134, an acceptance of service that is signed and dated by the party’s solicitor.

Subsection.Text: If an acknowledgement of service under paragraph (1)(c) is signed by a person on behalf of a solicitor, the person shall sign his or her own name.

Section.Text: If a document has been served in a manner that is not authorized by these Rules or by an order of the Court, the Court may validate the service if it is satisfied that the document came to the notice of the person to be served or that it would have come to that person’s notice except for the person’s avoidance of service.

Section.MarginalNote: Where document does not reach person served
Section.Text: On the motion of a party who did not have notice of a served document or did not obtain notice of it at the time of service, the Court may set aside the consequences of default or grant an extension of time or an adjournment, notwithstanding that the party was served with the document in accordance with these Rules.

Subsection.Text: A person who pays money into court shall deliver to the Registry

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a certified cheque or other bill of exchange drawn on a bank, trust company, credit union or caisse populaire or any other bill of exchange authorized by order of the Court, payable to the order of the Receiver General; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: three paper copies of a tender of payment into court in Form 149.

Subsection.Text: Payment into court by a certified cheque or other bill of exchange that is paid on presentation for payment is effective on the day on which it was delivered to the Registry.

When a certified cheque or other bill of exchange is paid, the Administrator shall endorse or acknowledge receipt on a copy of the tender of payment into court and return it to the person who made the payment.

Section.Text: Where an order has been made by the Court for payment out of court of money that is in the Consolidated Revenue Fund, a requisition shall be made by the Administrator to the Receiver General for an instrument for the amount to be paid out.

Subsection.Text: On motion, the Court may order that material to be filed shall be treated as confidential.

Before making an order under subsection (1), the Court must be satisfied that the material should be treated as confidential, notwithstanding the public interest in open and accessible court proceedings.

Where the material is required by law to be treated confidentially or where the Court orders that material be treated confidentially, a party who files the material shall separate and clearly mark it as confidential, identifying the legislative provision or the Court order under which it is required to be treated as confidential.
Unless otherwise ordered by the Court,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: only a solicitor of record, or a solicitor assisting in the proceeding, who is not a party is entitled to have access to confidential material;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: confidential material shall be given to a solicitor of record for a party only if the solicitor gives a written undertaking to the Court that he or she will

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: not disclose its content except to solicitors assisting in the proceeding or to the Court in the course of argument,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: not permit it to be reproduced in whole or in part, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: destroy the material and any notes on its content and file a certificate of their destruction or deliver the material and notes as ordered by the Court, when the material and notes are no longer required for the proceeding or the solicitor ceases to be solicitor of record;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: only one copy of any confidential material shall be given to the solicitor of record for each party; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: no confidential material or any information derived therefrom shall be disclosed to the public.

Subsection.Text: An order made under subsection (1) continues in effect until the Court orders otherwise, including for the duration of any appeal of the proceeding and after final judgment.

The Court may, for the purpose of making an inquiry and report, refer any question of fact in a proceeding to a judge or other person designated by the Chief Justice of the court before which the proceeding is pending.
Notwithstanding rules 155 to 160, the Court may at any time give directions regarding the conduct of a reference.

Section.Text: Where a reference is made under rule 153, on motion, the Court may stay any proceeding related to the reference, including a proceeding that has previously been stayed, for a period of not more than six months.

Section.MarginalNote: Requisition to fix time and place of reference

Subsection.Text: On a reference made under rule 153, the referee shall, on the requisition of a party, fix a time and place for the hearing of the reference.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Documents to be provided to referee
Subsection.Text: A party who makes a requisition under subsection (1) shall provide the referee with a statement of the issues and copies of the pleadings and order of reference.

Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, a referee shall adopt the simplest, least expensive and most expeditious manner of conducting the reference.

A referee may order that parties be examined for discovery and order the production for inspection and copying by a party of any document or other material relevant to a matter in issue, at the time and place and in the manner set out in the order.

Subsection.Text: The attendance of witnesses to give evidence at a reference shall be enforced by subpoena.
The testimony of a witness at a reference shall be recorded.
Subject to subsection (2), a referee shall have the same power and authority in matters of practice and procedure as would a judge of the Court presiding at the trial of an action.
A referee shall not commit a person to prison or enforce an order for attachment.
A referee may, before the conclusion of a reference or by a report on the reference, submit any question for determination by the Court.
On receipt of a submission under subsection (1), the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: require any explanations or reasons from the referee; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: remit the matter, or any part thereof, for further inquiry to the same or another referee.

Subsection.Text: The report of a referee shall include the findings of the referee in the same form as an order of the Court.

The report of a referee, the record of any evidence taken at the hearing of the reference and any exhibits or other documents provided to the referee shall be filed as soon as possible after the report is signed.
On the filing of a referee’s report, the Administrator shall send without delay a copy of it to all parties

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by registered mail;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by electronic means, including facsimile and electronic mail; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: by any other means, as directed by the Chief Justice, likely to bring the report to the attention of the party.

Subsection.Text: If a report is transmitted by electronic means, the Administrator shall confirm receipt by the party and place proof of that receipt on the Court file.

Section.MarginalNote: Report of referee who is a judge
Section.Text: The report of a referee who is a judge is final and becomes a judgment of the Court when it is filed.

Subsection.Text: A party may appeal the findings of a report of a referee who is not a judge on motion to the court that ordered the reference.
Notice of a motion under subsection (1) shall be served and filed within 30 days after filing of the report of a referee and at least 10 days before the day fixed for hearing of the motion.

On an appeal under subsection (1), the Court may confirm, vary or reverse the findings of the report and deliver judgment or refer it back to the referee, or to another referee, for further inquiry and report.
The report of a referee who is not a judge that is not appealed becomes final 30 days after it is filed.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Final report deemed judgment of Court
Subsection.Text: A report of a referee, once final, becomes a judgment of the Court.

Section.Text: A party may discontinue all or part of a proceeding by serving and filing a notice of discontinuance.
A party shall file a declaration of settlement or a notice of discontinuance in Form 166 in a proceeding that has been concluded other than by a judgment or discontinuance on consent.

The Court may, at any time, on the motion of a party who is not in default of any requirement of these Rules, dismiss a proceeding or impose other sanctions on the ground that there has been undue delay by a plaintiff, applicant or appellant in prosecuting the proceeding.
Where following an order of the Court it is not possible to continue a proceeding, the Court may dismiss the proceeding.
This Part applies to all proceedings that are not applications or appeals, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: references under section 18 of the Citizenship Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: applications under subsection 33(1) of the Marine Liability Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other proceedings required or permitted by or under an Act of Parliament to be brought as an action.

Section.MarginalNote: Rules applicable to counterclaims and third parties
Section.Text: Except as provided in rules 189 to 199, the rules in this Part applicable to plaintiffs and defendants apply, with such modifications as are necessary, to parties bringing or defending counterclaims and third party claims.
The following pleadings may be filed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an action,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement of claim, in Form 171A,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement of defence, in Form 171B, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a reply, in Form 171C;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a counterclaim,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a counterclaim, in Form 171D or 171E,,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a defence to counterclaim, in Form 171F, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a reply to a defence to counterclaim, in Form 171G; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a third party claim,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a third party claim, in Form 171H or 171I,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a third party defence, in Form 171J, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a reply to a third party defence, in Form 171K.

Section.Text: No pleading may be filed after a reply without leave of the Court.

Subsection.Text: Pleadings shall be divided into consecutively numbered paragraphs.
Every allegation in a pleading shall, as far as is practicable, be set out in a separate paragraph.

Section.Text: Every pleading shall contain a concise statement of the material facts on which the party relies, but shall not include evidence by which those facts are to be proved.
A party may raise any point of law in a pleading.

Subsection.Text: The performance or occurrence of a condition precedent to the assertion of a claim or defence need not be pleaded.
The non-performance or non-occurrence of a condition precedent shall be pleaded.

Section.Text: A pleading shall briefly describe any document or conversation referred to in the pleading, but need not set out the exact words of the document or conversation unless the words are themselves material.
A party may plead claims or defences in the alternative.
A party may plead a fact that occurs after the commencement of an action, even though the fact gives rise to a new claim or defence.
A party may plead an allegation of fact, or raise a new ground of claim in a pleading, that is inconsistent with a previous pleading only if the party amends the previous pleading accordingly.

Subsection.Text: A pleading shall contain particulars of every allegation contained therein, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of any alleged misrepresentation, fraud, breach of trust, wilful default or undue influence; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of any alleged state of mind of a person, including any alleged mental disorder or disability, malice or fraudulent intention.

Subsection.Text: On motion, the Court may order a party to serve and file further and better particulars of any allegation in its pleading

Section.Text: Every statement of claim, counterclaim and third party claim shall specify

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of any damages claimed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where monetary relief is claimed, whether the amount claimed, exclusive of interest and costs, exceeds $50,000;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the value of any property sought to be recovered;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other specific relief being claimed, other than costs; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the action is being proceeded with as a simplified action.

Section.Text: In a defence or subsequent pleading, a party shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: admit every allegation of material fact in the pleadings of every adverse party that is not disputed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where it is intended to prove a version of facts that differs from that relied on by an adverse party, plead that version of the facts; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: plead any matter or fact that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: might defeat a claim or defence of an adverse party, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: might take an adverse party by surprise if it were not pleaded.

Subsection.Text: All allegations of fact in a pleading that are not admitted are deemed to be denied.
Unless denied by an adverse party, it is not necessary that a party prove

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its right to claim in a representative capacity; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its constitution as a partnership, association or corporation.

Section.Text: Where a party alleges an agreement in a pleading, a bare denial of the agreement pleaded by another party shall be construed only as a denial of the making of the agreement or of the facts from which such an agreement may be implied and not as a denial of the legality or legal sufficiency of the agreement.

Where a claim to a sum of money, including a sum that is not ascertained, is relied on as a defence to all or part of a claim made by an adverse party, it may be included in a defence as a set-off against the claim, whether or not it is also added as a counterclaim.
Where judgments in an action and in a counterclaim are given at the same time, the Court may set off the amount of one award against the other, without prejudice as to costs.

Subject to section 31.2 of the Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, a defence of tender before action may not be pleaded unless the defendant has paid into court the amount alleged to have been tendered.

Subsection.Text: A defendant who claims to be entitled to relief against a plaintiff may make a counterclaim instead of bringing a separate action.
A counterclaim shall be included in the same document as the statement of defence.
A statement of defence and counterclaim shall contain a second style of cause identifying the plaintiff by counterclaim and the defendants to the counterclaim.

Section.Text: A counterclaim may be proceeded with notwithstanding that judgment is given in the action or that the action is stayed or discontinued.

Section.MarginalNote: Counterclaim against person not already a party

Subsection.Text: Where a defendant who counterclaims alleges that a person who is not a party to the action is liable to the defendant along with the plaintiff in respect of the subject-matter of the counterclaim, the defendant may join that person as a defendant to the counterclaim.
Where a defendant adds a person who is not already a party as a defendant to a counterclaim, the defendant's statement of defence and counterclaim shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: issued within the time set out in rule 204 for the service and filing of a statement of defence; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: served on the person and on the other parties within 30 days after it is issued.

Subsection.Text: A defendant to a counterclaim who is already a party to the action shall defend the counterclaim by serving and filing a defence to counterclaim within 30 days after service of the statement of defence and counterclaim.
A reply and a defence to counterclaim by a plaintiff against whom a counterclaim has been made shall be included in the same document.

Section.Text: A defendant may commence a third party claim against a co-defendant, or against a person who is not a party to the action, who the defendant claims is or may be liable to the defendant for all or part of the plaintiff's claim.
With leave of the Court, a defendant may commence a third party claim against a co-defendant, or against another person who is not a defendant to the action, who the defendant claims

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is or may be liable to the defendant for relief, other than that referred to in rule 193, relating to the subject-matter of the action; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: should be bound by the determination of an issue between the plaintiff and the defendant.

Section.Text: A third party claim against a co-defendant shall be served and filed within 10 days after the filing of the statement of defence.

Subsection.Text: A third party claim against a person who is not already a party to the action shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: issued within the time set out in rule 204 for the service and filing of a statement of defence; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: served within 30 days after it is issued.

Subsection.Text: A third party claim served on a person who is not already a party to the action shall be accompanied by a copy of all pleadings filed in the action.

Section.MarginalNote: Time for defence to third party claim

Subsection.Text: A third party shall defend the plaintiff's claim against the defendant by filing a statement of defence within the time set out in rule 204.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Rights and obligations of third party
Subsection.Text: A third party defending the plaintiff's claim against the defendant has the same procedural rights and obligations in the action as the defendant, including those in respect of discovery, trial and appeal.
Unless the Court orders otherwise, a third party claim shall be heard and decided as part of the action from which it arose.
The Court may order the question of liability as between the third party and the defendant to be tried in such a manner, at or after the trial of the action, as is set out in the order.

A third party is bound by any order or determination made in an action between the plaintiff and the defendant who made the third party claim, whether or not the third party defended the plaintiff's claim.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Consequences of default of third party defence
Subsection.Text: A third party who defends neither the third party claim nor the plaintiff's claim is deemed to admit

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the validity of any judgment obtained by the plaintiff against the defendant, including a judgment obtained by consent; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the third party's liability to contribute or indemnify to the extent specified in the third party claim.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Leave required to enforce default judgment
Subsection.Text: A judgment against a third party referred to in subsection (2) shall not be enforced without leave of the Court.

Section.Text: Notwithstanding rules 75 and 76, a party may, without leave, amend any of its pleadings at any time before another party has pleaded thereto or on the filing of the written consent of the other parties.

Section.MarginalNote: Amendment to add new cause of action
Section.Text: An amendment may be made under rule 76 notwithstanding that the effect of the amendment will be to add or substitute a new cause of action, if the new cause of action arises out of substantially the same facts as a cause of action in respect of which the party seeking the amendment has already claimed relief in the action.
Pleadings are closed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where a statement of defence has not been filed within the period set out in rule 204, on the expiration of that period;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the filing of a reply; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on the expiration of the time for filing a reply.

Subsection.Text: A statement of claim shall be served within 60 days after it is issued.
Proof of service of a statement of claim shall be filed within the time set out in rule 204 for the service and filing of a statement of defence.

Section.Text: A defendant shall defend an action by serving and filing a statement of defence within

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 30 days after service of the statement of claim, if the defendant is served in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 40 days after service of the statement of claim, if the defendant is served in the United States; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 60 days after service of the statement of claim, if the defendant is served outside Canada and the United States.

Section.Text: A plaintiff's reply to a statement of defence shall be served and filed within 10 days after service of the statement of defence.
A copy of every document referred to in a pleading shall be served with the pleading or within 10 days after service of the pleading, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the party being served waives its right to the copy; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Court orders otherwise.

Section.MarginalNote: Service of counterclaim where no new party added

Subsection.Text: Where a counterclaim is brought against a plaintiff only, or against only a plaintiff and another party to the action, the statement of defence and counterclaim shall be served and filed within the time set out in rule 204.

Where a defendant to a counterclaim who is also a defendant in the action has failed to file a statement of defence in the action, that defendant shall be served personally with a statement of defence and counterclaim.

Section.Text: A party who has been served with a statement of claim and who brings a motion to object to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any irregularity in the commencement of the action,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the service of the statement of claim,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Court as not being a convenient forum, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the jurisdiction of the Court,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: does not thereby attorn to the jurisdiction of the Court.

Section.Text: A solicitor appearing for a party bringing a motion referred to in rule 208 shall be considered to be the solicitor of record of the party and the address indicated for the solicitor on the notice of motion or other documents is the address for service of the party.

Subsection.Text: Where a defendant fails to serve and file a statement of defence within the time set out in rule 204 or any other time fixed by an order of the Court, the plaintiff may bring a motion for judgment against the defendant on the statement of claim.
Subject to section 25 of the Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, a motion under subsection (1) may be brought ex parte and in accordance with rule 369.
A motion under subsection (1) shall be supported by affidavit evidence.
On a motion under subsection (1), the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: grant judgment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dismiss the action; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: order that the action proceed to trial and that the plaintiff prove its case in such a manner as the Court may direct.

Section.MarginalNote: Service pursuant to order for substitutional service
Section.Text: Judgment shall not be given against a defendant who is in default where service of the statement of claim was effected pursuant to an order for substitutional service, unless the Court is satisfied that it is just to do so having regard to all the circumstances.

Subsection.Text: Where a statement of claim was sent abroad for service on a defendant in a contracting state to the Hague Convention and the defendant has not filed a defence, judgment shall not be given under rule 210 unless the Court is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the statement of claim was

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: served by a method prescribed by the law of the state in which service was made, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: delivered to the defendant or to the defendant's residence by another method provided for in the Hague Convention; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the defendant has had sufficient time after the service or delivery to file a defence.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsection (1), the Court may give judgment under rule 210 if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the statement of claim was sent by a method provided for in the Hague Convention;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a period of not less than six months, or such longer period as the Court considers adequate in the circumstances, has elapsed since the day on which the statement of claim was sent; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: no certificate under article 6 of the Hague Convention was received, and every reasonable effort was made to obtain such a certificate through the competent authorities of the state to which the statement of claim was sent.

Subsection.Text: This rule does not preclude the Court from making an order under rule 373 before service of the statement of claim.

A party may bring a motion for summary judgment or summary trial on all or some of the issues raised in the pleadings at any time after the defendant has filed a defence but before the time and place for trial have been fixed.
If a party brings a motion for summary judgment or summary trial, the party may not bring a further motion for either summary judgment or summary trial except with leave of the Court.

A motion for summary judgment or summary trial in an action may be brought by serving and filing a notice of motion and motion record at least 20 days before the day set out in the notice for the hearing of the motion.

A party served with a motion for summary judgment or summary trial shall serve and file a respondent’s motion record not later than 10 days before the day set out in the notice of motion for the hearing of the motion.

Section.Text: A response to a motion for summary judgment shall not rely on what might be adduced as evidence at a later stage in the proceedings. It must set out specific facts and adduce the evidence showing that there is a genuine issue for trial.

Section.MarginalNote: If no genuine issue for trial

Subsection.Text: If on a motion for summary judgment the Court is satisfied that there is no genuine issue for trial with respect to a claim or defence, the Court shall grant summary judgment accordingly.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Genuine issue of amount or question of law
Subsection.Text: If the Court is satisfied that the only genuine issue is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the amount to which the moving party is entitled, the Court may order a trial of that issue or grant summary judgment with a reference under rule 153 to determine the amount; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a question of law, the Court may determine the question and grant summary judgment accordingly.

Subsection.Text: If the Court is satisfied that there is a genuine issue of fact or law for trial with respect to a claim or a defence, the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: nevertheless determine that issue by way of summary trial and make any order necessary for the conduct of the summary trial; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dismiss the motion in whole or in part and order that the action, or the issues in the action not disposed of by summary judgment, proceed to trial or that the action be conducted as a specially managed proceeding.

Subsection.Text: The motion record for a summary trial shall contain all of the evidence on which a party seeks to rely, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: affidavits;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: admissions under rule 256;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: affidavits or statements of an expert witness prepared in accordance with subsection 258(5); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any part of the evidence that would be admissible under rules 288 and 289.

Subsection.Text: No further affidavits or statements may be served, except

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the moving party, if their content is limited to evidence that would be admissible at trial as rebuttal evidence and they are served and filed at least 5 days before the day set out in the notice of motion for the hearing of the summary trial; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with leave of the Court.

Subsection.Text: The Court may make any order required for the conduct of the summary trial, including an order requiring a deponent or an expert who has given a statement to attend for cross-examination before the Court.
The Court may draw an adverse inference if a party fails to cross-examine on an affidavit or to file responding or rebuttal evidence.
The Court shall dismiss the motion if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the issues raised are not suitable for summary trial; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a summary trial would not assist in the efficient resolution of the action.

Subsection.Text: If the Court is satisfied that there is sufficient evidence for adjudication, regardless of the amounts involved, the complexities of the issues and the existence of conflicting evidence, the Court may grant judgment either generally or on an issue, unless the Court is of the opinion that it would be unjust to decide the issues on the motion.
On granting judgment, the Court may make any order necessary for the disposition of the action, including an order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: directing a trial to determine the amount to which the moving party is entitled or a reference under rule 153 to determine that amount;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: imposing terms respecting the enforcement of the judgment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: awarding costs.

Subsection.Text: If the motion for summary trial is dismissed in whole or in part, the Court may order the action, or the issues in the action not disposed of by summary trial, to proceed to trial or order that the action be conducted as a specially managed proceeding.

Section.MarginalNote: Right of plaintiff who obtains judgment
Section.Text: A plaintiff who obtains judgment under rule 215 or 216 may proceed against the same defendant for any other relief and may proceed against any other defendant for the same or any other relief.

If judgment under rule 215 or 216 is refused or is granted only in part, the Court may make an order specifying which material facts are not in dispute and defining the issues to be tried and may also make an order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for payment into court of all or part of the claim;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for security for costs; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: limiting the nature and scope of the examination for discovery to matters not covered by the affidavits filed on the motion for summary judgment or summary trial or by any cross-examination on them and providing for their use at trial in the same manner as an examination for discovery.

Section.Text: On granting judgment under rule 215 or 216, the Court may order that enforcement of the judgment be stayed pending the determination of any other issue in the action or in a counterclaim or third party claim.

Section.MarginalNote: Preliminary determination of question of law or admissibility

Subsection.Text: A party may bring a motion before trial to request that the Court determine

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a question of law that may be relevant to an action;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a question as to the admissibility of any document, exhibit or other evidence; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: questions stated by the parties in the form of a special case before, or in lieu of, the trial of the action.

Subsection.Text: Where, on a motion under subsection (1), the Court orders that a question be determined, it shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: give directions as to the case on which the question shall be argued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fix time limits for the filing and service of motion records by the parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fix a time and place for argument of the question.

Subsection.Text: A determination of a question referred to in subsection (1) is final and conclusive for the purposes of the action, subject to being varied on appeal.
On motion, the Court may, at any time, order that a pleading, or anything contained therein, be struck out, with or without leave to amend, on the ground that it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: discloses no reasonable cause of action or defence, as the case may be,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is immaterial or redundant,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is scandalous, frivolous or vexatious,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: may prejudice or delay the fair trial of the action,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: constitutes a departure from a previous pleading, or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: is otherwise an abuse of the process of the Court,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and may order the action be dismissed or judgment entered accordingly.

Subsection.Text: No evidence shall be heard on a motion for an order under paragraph (1)(a).

In rules 223 to 232 and 295, document includes an audio recording, a video recording, a film, a photograph, a chart, a graph, a map, a plan, a survey and a book of account, as well as data that is recorded or stored on any medium in or by a computer system or other similar device and that can be read or perceived by a person or a computer system or other similar device.

For the purposes of rules 223 to 232 and 295, a document of a party is relevant if the party intends to rely on it or if the document tends to adversely affect the party's case or to support another party's case.

Section.MarginalNote: Time for service of affidavit of documents

Subsection.Text: Every party shall serve an affidavit of documents on every other party within 30 days after the close of pleadings.
An affidavit of documents shall be in Form 223 and shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: separate lists and descriptions of all relevant documents that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are in the possession, power or control of the party and for which no privilege is claimed,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are or were in the possession, power or control of the party and for which privilege is claimed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: were but are no longer in the possession, power or control of the party and for which no privilege is claimed, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the party believes are in the possession, power or control of a person who is not a party to the action;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the grounds for each claim of privilege in respect of a document;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of how the party lost possession, power or control of any document and its current location, as far as the party can determine;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the identity of each person referred to in subparagraph (a)(iv), including the person's name and address, if known;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a statement that the party is not aware of any relevant document, other than those that are listed in the affidavit or are or were in the possession, power or control of another party to the action; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an indication of the time and place at which the documents referred to in subparagraph (a)(i) may be inspected.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Document within party's power or control
Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2), a document shall be considered to be within a party's power or control if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the party is entitled to obtain the original document or a copy of it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no adverse party is so entitled.

Subsection.Text: A party may treat a bundle of documents as a single document for the purposes of an affidavit of documents if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the documents are all of the same nature; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the bundle is described in sufficient detail to enable another party to clearly ascertain its contents.

Subsection.Text: The deponent of an affidavit of documents shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the party is an individual who is not under a legal disability, the party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the party is an individual under a legal disability, a person appointed under rule 115;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the party is a corporation or an unincorporated association, an authorized representative of the corporation or association; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the party is the Crown, an authorized representative of the Crown.

Subsection.Text: The deponent of an affidavit of documents shall, before making the affidavit, become informed by making reasonable inquiries of any present or former officer, servant, agent or employee of the party, including any who are outside Canada, who might reasonably be expected to have knowledge relating to any matter in question in the action.
The solicitor of record for a party shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: explain to the deponent of an affidavit of documents the necessity of making full disclosure under rule 223 and the possible consequences of failing to do so; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: certify on the affidavit of documents or on a document attached to it that those explanations have been given.

Section.Text: On motion, the Court may order a party to disclose in an affidavit of documents all relevant documents that are in the possession, power or control of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the party is an individual, any corporation that is controlled directly or indirectly by the party; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the party is a corporation,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any corporation that is controlled directly or indirectly by the party,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any corporation or individual that directly or indirectly controls the party, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any corporation that is controlled directly or indirectly by a person who also directly or indirectly controls the party.

Subsection.Text: A party who becomes aware that its affidavit of documents is inaccurate or deficient shall, without delay, serve a supplementary affidavit of documents correcting the inaccuracy or deficiency.
A document produced and marked as an exhibit on an examination need not be included in a supplementary affidavit of documents.

Section.Text: On motion, where the Court is satisfied that an affidavit of documents is inaccurate or deficient, the Court may inspect any document that may be relevant and may order that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the deponent of the affidavit be cross-examined;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an accurate or complete affidavit be served and filed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all or part of the pleadings of the party on behalf of whom the affidavit was made be struck out; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that the party on behalf of whom the affidavit was made pay costs.

Subsection.Text: Subject to rule 230, a party who has served an affidavit of documents on another party shall, during business hours, allow the other party to inspect and, where practicable, to copy any document referred to in the affidavit that is not privileged, if the document is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the possession of the party; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the power or control of the party and the other party requests that it be made available because the other party cannot otherwise inspect or copy it.

Subsection.Text: A party who has served an affidavit of documents on another party shall, at the request of the other party, deliver to the other party a copy of any document referred to in subsection (1), if the other party pays the cost of the copies and of their delivery.

Section.Text: On motion, the Court may order the production for inspection and copying by a party of any document referred to in subsection 228(1), at a time and place and in a manner set out in the order.
On motion, the Court may relieve a party from production for inspection of any document, having regard to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the issues in the case and the order in which they are likely to be resolved; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether it would be unduly onerous to require the person to produce the document.

Section.Text: The disclosure of a document or its production for inspection does not constitute an admission of its authenticity or admissibility in the action.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise or discovery of documents has been waived by the parties, no document shall be used in evidence unless it has been

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: disclosed on a party's affidavit of documents as a document for which no privilege has been claimed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: produced for inspection by a party, or a person examined on behalf of one of the parties, on or subsequent to examinations for discovery; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: produced by a witness who is not, in the opinion of the Court, under control of the party.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to a document that is used solely as a foundation for, or as a part of a question in, cross-examination or re-examination.

On motion, the Court may order the production of any document that is in the possession of a person who is not a party to the action, if the document is relevant and its production could be compelled at trial.
Notice of a motion for an order under subsection (1) shall be personally served on the person who is in possession of the document.
The Court may, in an order under subsection (1), give directions for the preparation of a certified copy of the document to be used instead of the original.

A party may conduct an examination for discovery by way of both an oral and a written examination only with leave of the Court or with the consent of the person being examined and all other parties entitled to examine that person.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Oral examination by two or more parties
Subsection.Text: Where two or more parties are entitled to examine a person, the examination for discovery shall be by way of an oral examination, except with leave of the Court or with the consent of the person being examined and all other parties entitled to examine that person.

Section.Text: Except with leave of the Court, a party may examine for discovery any adverse party only once.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a party may examine an adverse party for discovery only if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pleadings are closed and the examining party has served its affidavit of documents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pleadings are closed and the adverse party consents to the examination being conducted before the examining party has served its affidavit of documents; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the adverse party is in default of serving and filing its pleadings and leave of the Court has been obtained.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), a defendant may examine a plaintiff at any time after the statement of claim is filed.
Where two or more defendants are represented by the same solicitor, none of them may examine the plaintiff before filing a defence unless all of them examine the plaintiff at the same time.
A corporation, partnership or unincorporated association that is to be examined for discovery shall select a representative to be examined on its behalf.
Where the Crown is to be examined for discovery, the Attorney General of Canada shall select a representative to be examined on its behalf.
The Court may, on the motion of a party entitled to examine a person selected under subsection (1) or (2), order that some other person be examined.
Where an assignee is a party to an action, the assignor may also be examined for discovery.
Where a trustee in bankruptcy is a party to an action, the bankrupt may also be examined for discovery.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Examination of party under legal disability
Subsection.Text: If a party intends to examine for discovery a person who is appointed under paragraph 115(1)(b) to represent a person under a legal disability, the party may, with leave of the Court, also examine the person under a legal disability.

Where a party intends to examine for discovery a person bringing or defending an action on behalf of another person who is not a party, with leave of the Court, the party may also examine that other person.

A party to an action may bring a motion for leave to examine for discovery any person not a party to the action, other than an expert witness for a party, who might have information on an issue in the action.
On a motion under subsection (1), the notice of motion shall be served on the other parties and personally served on the person to be examined.
The Court may, on a motion under subsection (1), grant leave to examine a person and determine the time and manner of conducting the examination, if it is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person may have information on an issue in the action;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the party has been unable to obtain the information informally from the person or from another source by any other reasonable means;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it would be unfair not to allow the party an opportunity to question the person before trial; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the questioning will not cause undue delay, inconvenience or expense to the person or to the other parties.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, a party who is granted leave to examine a person under rule 238 shall pay to the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least 10 days before the day of the examination, an amount sufficient to cover reasonable travel expenses; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within 10 days after the examination, an amount sufficient to cover any reasonable travel expenses in excess of the initial payment.

Subsection.Text: A person being examined under rule 238 is entitled to be assisted by a solicitor.
On motion, the Court may, in special circumstances, order that the costs of a solicitor assisting a person to be examined under rule 238 be included in the amounts paid under subsection (1).
A person being examined under rule 238 may also be questioned by any other party.
A person being examined under rule 238 shall not be cross-examined and shall not be required to give hearsay evidence.

The testimony of a person who was examined under rule 238 shall not be used as evidence at trial but, if the person is a witness at trial, it may be used in cross-examination in the same manner as any written statement of a witness.

Section.Text: A person being examined for discovery shall answer, to the best of the person's knowledge, information and belief, any question that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is relevant to any unadmitted allegation of fact in a pleading filed by the party being examined or by the examining party; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: concerns the name or address of any person, other than an expert witness, who might reasonably be expected to have knowledge relating to a matter in question in the action.

Section.Text: Subject to paragraph 242(1)(d), a person who is to be examined for discovery, other than a person examined under rule 238, shall, before the examination, become informed by making inquiries of any present or former officer, servant, agent or employee of the party, including any who are outside Canada, who might be expected to have knowledge relating to any matter in question in the action.

Subsection.Text: A person may object to a question asked in an examination for discovery on the ground that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the answer is privileged;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the question is not relevant to any unadmitted allegation of fact in a pleading filed by the party being examined or by the examining party;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the question is unreasonable or unnecessary; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: it would be unduly onerous to require the person to make the inquiries referred to in rule 241.

Subsection.Text: A person other than a person examined under rule 238 may not object to a question asked in an examination for discovery on the ground that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the answer would be evidence or hearsay;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the question constitutes cross-examination.

Section.Text: On motion, the Court may limit an examination for discovery that it considers to be oppressive, vexatious or unnecessary.

Section.MarginalNote: Examined party to be better informed

Subsection.Text: Where a person being examined for discovery, other than a person examined under rule 238, is unable to answer a question, the examining party may require the person to become better informed and may conclude the examination, subject to obtaining answers to any remaining questions.

A person being examined who is required to become better informed shall provide the information sought by the examining party by submitting to a continuation of the oral examination for discovery in respect of the information or, where the parties agree, by providing the information in writing.
Information provided under subsection (2) is deemed to be part of the examination for discovery.

A person who was examined for discovery and who discovers that the answer to a question in the examination is no longer correct or complete shall, without delay, provide the examining party with the corrected or completed information in writing.
An examining party may require a person providing information under subsection (1) to continue the examination for discovery in respect of that information.
Information provided under subsection (1) is deemed to be part of the examination for discovery.
The solicitor of a person being examined for discovery orally may answer a question on behalf of the person during the examination, unless the examining party objects.
An answer given by a solicitor under subsection (1) is deemed to be the answer of the person being examined for discovery.

Section.Text: Where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an order was made under rule 153 that an issue of fact be the subject of a reference after trial, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an order was made under rule 107 that an issue in the action be determined separately,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: any subsequent examination for discovery or inspection of documents shall not extend to that issue, unless otherwise ordered by the Court.

Section.Text: Where a party examined for discovery, or a person examined for discovery on behalf of a party, has refused, on the ground of privilege or for any other reason, to answer a proper question and has not subsequently answered the question, the party may not introduce the information sought by the question at trial without leave of the Court.

Subsection.Text: On motion, where the Court is satisfied that it is necessary or expedient for the purpose of obtaining information or evidence in full, the Court may order, in respect of any property that is the subject-matter of an action or as to which a question may arise therein, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a sample be taken of the property;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an inspection be made of the property; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an experiment be tried on or with the property.

Subsection.Text: An order made under subsection (1) may authorize a person to enter any land or building where the property is located for the purpose of enabling the order to be carried out.

Where a motion is brought under subsection (1) for an order in respect of property that is in the possession of a person who is not a party to the action, that person shall be personally served with notice of the motion.
In an action for damages for personal injuries, the Court may, on motion, order the injured person to submit to a medical examination at a place and by a medical practitioner appointed by the Court.

A person who is required to undergo a medical examination under this rule is entitled to have a solicitor, medical advisor or person appointed under rule 115, or all of them, present at the examination, but no other person, other than the person being examined and the medical practitioner authorized to conduct the examination, shall be present during the examination, except with leave of the Court or with the consent of the parties.

A medical practitioner who is examining a person under this rule may, in connection with that examination, ask the person any question that may be relevant to the purpose of the examination, and any statement made by the person during such an examination is admissible in evidence.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Sanctions for plaintiff's failure to comply
Subsection.Text: If a plaintiff fails, without reasonable excuse, to comply with an order under subsection (1) or to answer any questions referred to in subsection (3), the Court may dismiss the action.

Section.Text: On motion, the Court may order further medical examinations in accordance with rule 250, on such terms as it considers just.

Subsection.Text: After conducting a medical examination under rule 250, the medical practitioner shall prepare a written report setting out his or her observations, the results of any tests made and his or her conclusions, diagnosis and prognosis and forthwith provide the report to the party who obtained the order.
A party who obtains an order under rule 250 shall forthwith serve the report obtained pursuant to it on every other party.
Every person who receives a medical report under this rule shall treat it as confidential and use it only for the purposes of the action.

Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, a medical practitioner who has made an examination under an order made under subsection 250(1) may, subject to rule 279, be called as a witness at trial.

The Court may order that a party seeking an order under subsection 250(1) or rule 251 pay to the person to be examined or to a representative of the person appointed under rule 115 all necessary expenses of attending the examination.

Section.MarginalNote: Request to admit fact or document
Section.Text: A party may, after pleadings have been closed, request that another party admit a fact or the authenticity of a document by serving a request to admit, in Form 255, on that party.

A party who is served with a request to admit is deemed to admit a fact or the authenticity of a document set out in the request to admit unless that party serves a response to the request in Form 256 within 20 days after its service and denies the admission, setting out the grounds for the denial.

Within 60 days after the close of pleadings, the solicitors for the parties shall discuss the possibility of settling any or all of the issues in the action and of bringing a motion to refer any unsettled issues to a dispute resolution conference.

Subsection.Text: After the close of pleadings, a party who is not in default under these Rules or under an order of the Court and who is ready for trial may serve and file a requisition for a pre-trial conference, accompanied by a pre-trial conference memorandum.
A requisition for a pre-trial conference shall be in Form 258 and include a certification by the solicitor of record that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all examinations for discovery that the party intends to conduct have been completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: settlement discussions have taken place in accordance with rule 257.

Subsection.Text: A pre-trial conference memorandum shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a concise statement of the nature of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any admissions of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the factual and legal contentions of the party; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the issues to be determined at trial.

Subsection.Text: A pre-trial conference memorandum shall be accompanied by a copy of all documents that are intended to be used at trial that may be of assistance at the pre-trial conference, including all affidavits or statements of expert witnesses.

Section.MarginalNote: Time and place for pre-trial conference
Section.Text: On the filing of a requisition for a pre-trial conference, the Court shall fix a time, not more than 60 days thereafter, and place for the pre-trial conference.
Unless the Court directs otherwise, the solicitors of record for the parties and the parties or their authorized representatives shall participate in a pre-trial conference.
The Administrator shall serve a notice of pre-trial conference, in Form 261, on the parties at least 30 days before the date fixed for the conference.

Subsection.Text: Every party, other than the party who filed the requisition for a pre-trial conference, shall serve and file a pre-trial conference memorandum within 30 days after being served with the requisition.

The pre-trial conference memorandum shall include any known objection to the requisitioning party’s proposed expert witness that could disqualify the witness from testifying and the basis for the objection.

Section.Text: Participants at a pre-trial conference must be prepared to address

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility of settlement of any or all of the issues in the action and of referring any unsettled issues to a dispute resolution conference;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: simplification of the issues in the action;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any issues arising from any affidavits or statements of expert witnesses, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any objection to an opposing party’s proposed expert witness that could disqualify the witness from testifying and the basis for the objection,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any benefit to the litigation in ordering the experts to confer with one another in advance of trial in order to narrow the issues and identify the points on which their views differ, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the need for any additional or rebuttal expert witness evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility of obtaining admissions that may facilitate the trial;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the issue of liability;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the amount of damages, where damages are claimed;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated duration of the trial;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the advisability of having the Court appoint an assessor;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the advisability of a reference;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: suitable dates for a trial;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the necessity for interpreters or simultaneous interpretation at the trial;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: whether a notice of a constitutional question needs to be served under section 57 of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the content of the trial record; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter that may promote the timely and just disposition of the action.

Section.Text: A judge or prothonotary who conducts a pre-trial conference shall fix the place of trial and assign a date for trial at the earliest practicable date after the pre-trial conference.

Subsection.Text: At a pre-trial conference,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judge may make any order respecting the conduct of the action; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a prothonotary may make any order respecting the conduct of the action other than an order under a motion referred to in any of paragraphs 50(1)(a) to (i).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Service of expert’s affidavit or statement
Subsection.Text: If applicable, the order shall set out the time for service of any additional or rebuttal affidavits or statements of expert witnesses.

Section.MarginalNote: Pre-trial judge not to preside at trial
Section.Text: A judge or prothonotary who conducts a pre-trial conference in an action shall not preside at the trial of the action unless all parties consent.

No communication shall be made to a judge or prothonotary presiding at a trial or hearing, or on a motion or reference in an action, with respect to any statement made at a pre-trial conference, except as may be permitted in an order made at the conclusion of the pre-trial conference or as consented to by the parties.
The plaintiff, or any other party so directed by the Court at a pre-trial conference, shall serve and file a trial record not later than 40 days before the date fixed for trial.
A trial record shall contain the pleadings, any particulars, all orders and directions respecting the trial and any other filed document that is necessary for the conduct of the trial.

Notwithstanding rule 266, a judge or prothonotary before whom an action has been set down for trial may, without being disqualified from presiding at the trial, hold a conference, either before or during the trial, to consider any matter that may assist in the just and timely disposition of the action.

Heading.TitleText: Taking of Trial Evidence out of Court

Subsection.Text: On motion, the Court may order the examination for trial of a person out of court.
In making an order under subsection (1), the Court may consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the expected absence of the person at the time of trial;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the age or any infirmity of the person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the distance the person resides from the place of trial; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the expense of having the person attend at trial.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Directions regarding taking evidence before trial
Subsection.Text: In an order under subsection (1), or on the subsequent motion of a party, the Court may give directions regarding the time, place, manner and costs of the examination, notice to be given to the person being examined and to other parties, the attendance of witnesses and the production of requested documents or material.

On motion, the Court may order the further examination, before the Court or before a person designated by the Court, of any witness examined under subsection (1), and if such an examination is not conducted, the Court may refuse to admit the evidence of that witness.

Where an examination under rule 271 is to be made outside Canada, the Court may order the issuance of a commission under the seal of the Court, letters rogatory, a letter of request or any other document necessary for the examination in Form 272A, 272B or 272C, as the case may be.

A person authorized under subsection (1) to take the examination of a witness in a jurisdiction outside Canada shall, unless the parties agree otherwise or the Court orders otherwise, take the examination in a manner that is binding on the witness under the law of that jurisdiction.

Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, evidence obtained on an examination under subsection 271(1) or (4) may, without further proof, be used in evidence by any party.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), at the trial of an action, unless the Court directs otherwise,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the plaintiff shall make an opening address and then adduce evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the plaintiff's evidence is concluded, the defendant shall make an opening address and then adduce evidence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when the defendant's evidence is concluded, the plaintiff may adduce reply evidence.

Subsection.Text: Where the Court has made an order permitting two or more plaintiffs to put in separate cases, or where more than one defendant is separately represented, the order of presentation shall be as directed by the Court.

Section.Text: The Court may give directions at trial concerning the method of proving a fact or of adducing evidence.
All exhibits adduced in evidence shall be marked and numbered.
The Court may, in the presence of solicitors for the parties, inspect any place or thing in respect of which a question may arise at trial.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court directs otherwise, the parties shall be heard in argument, after all parties have been given full opportunity to put in their respective cases, in the order in which they adduced evidence.
A party shall have a right of reply to the arguments of adverse parties and, if the party raises a new point of law, an adverse party may answer on that point.

Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, no expert witness’s evidence is admissible at the trial of an action in respect of any issue unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the issue has been defined by the pleadings or in an order made under rule 265;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an affidavit or statement of the expert witness prepared in accordance with rule 52.2 has been served in accordance with subsection 258(1), rule 262 or an order made under rule 265; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the expert witness is available at the trial for cross-examination.

Section.MarginalNote: Tendering of expert’s evidence at trial

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, evidence in chief of an expert witness may be tendered at trial by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the witness reading into evidence all or part of an affidavit or statement referred to in paragraph 279(b); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the witness explaining any of the content of an affidavit or statement that has been read into evidence.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), an expert witness may tender other evidence in chief with leave of the Court.
With leave of the Court, all or part of an affidavit or statement referred to in paragraph 279(b) may be taken as read into evidence by the witness.
Except with leave of the Court, there shall be no cross-examination before trial on an affidavit or statement referred to in paragraph 279(b).
Unless the Court orders otherwise, witnesses at trial shall be examined orally and in open court.
All witnesses shall testify under oath.

Section.Text: The Court may require that some or all of the expert witnesses testify as a panel after the completion of the testimony of the non-expert witnesses of each party or at any other time that the Court may determine.

Subsection.Text: Expert witnesses shall give their views and may be directed to comment on the views of other panel members and to make concluding statements. With leave of the Court, they may pose questions to other panel members.
On completion of the testimony of the panel, the panel members may be cross-examined and re-examined in the sequence directed by Court.

Section.Text: Rule 93 applies, with such modifications as are necessary, to the use of an interpreter at trial.

Subsection.Text: Where on the day of a trial, a party who intends to call witnesses does not produce them or justify their absence, the Court may declare the party's proof closed.
