Subject to subsection (3), where a party demonstrates due diligence and the Court is satisfied that an absent witness is necessary and that the absence of the witness is not due to any contrivance on the party's part, the Court may adjourn the hearing.

An adverse party may require a party seeking an adjournment under subsection (2) to declare, or to produce some other person to declare, under oath the facts that, in the opinion of the party seeking the adjournment, the defaulting witness would have stated, and may avoid the adjournment by admitting the truth of those facts or that the witness would have stated those facts.

Section.Text: The Court may, at any time, order that any fact be proven by affidavit or that the affidavit of a witness be read at trial.
The Court may, before trial, order that evidence of any fact be given at the trial in such a manner as may be specified in the order, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by statement on oath of information or belief;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by the production of documents or other material;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: by the production of copies of documents; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a fact that is or was a matter of common knowledge either generally or in a particular district, by the production of a specified publication containing a statement of that fact.

Section.Text: Except with leave of the Court, no plan, photograph, model or other demonstrative evidence prepared or obtained for use at trial is admissible in evidence at trial, other than in the course of cross-examination, unless at least 30 days before the commencement of the trial all other parties have been given an opportunity to inspect it and consent to its admission without further proof.

Heading.TitleText: Use of Examination for Discovery at Trial

Section.Text: A party may introduce as its own evidence at trial any part of its examination for discovery of an adverse party or of a person examined on behalf of an adverse party, whether or not the adverse party or person has already testified.

The Court may order a party who uses part of an examination for discovery as its own evidence to introduce into evidence any other part of the examination for discovery that the Court considers is so related that it ought not to be omitted.
The Court may permit a party to use all or part of an examination for discovery of a person, other than a person examined under rule 238, as evidence at trial if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person is unable to testify at the trial because of his or her illness, infirmity or death or because the person cannot be compelled to attend; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: his or her evidence cannot be obtained on commission.

Section.MarginalNote: Use of examination to impeach credibility at trial
Section.Text: A party may use any part of its examination for discovery of a person as evidence to impeach the credibility of that person as a witness at trial only if the party first puts to the person the questions asked in that part of the examination.
Unless the Court orders otherwise, rules 294 to 299 apply to any action in which

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: each claim is exclusively for monetary relief in an amount not exceeding $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an action in rem claiming monetary relief, no amount claimed, exclusive of interest and costs, exceeds $50,000;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the parties agree that the action is to be conducted as a simplified action; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on motion, the Court orders that the action be conducted as a simplified action.

Section.MarginalNote: Cost consequences of improper avoidance of procedure
Section.Text: The Court may award costs against any party, including a party who is successful in an action, who it finds has exaggerated a claim, including a counterclaim or third party claim, merely to avoid the operation of rules 292 and 294 to 299.
Every pleading in a simplified action shall be prefaced by the heading "Simplified Action".

A party to a simplified action may serve, in lieu of an affidavit of documents, a complete list of all the documents in the party's possession, power or control that are relevant to a matter in issue in the action.
An examination for discovery in a simplified action shall be in writing only, and shall not exceed 50 questions.

Section.MarginalNote: Motion for summary judgment or summary trial
Section.Text: No motion for summary judgment or summary trial may be brought in a simplified action.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a motion in a simplified action shall be returnable only at a pre-trial conference conducted in accordance with rules 258 to 267.
A motion may be brought, within the time set out in rule 204 for the service and filing of a statement of defence,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to object to the jurisdiction of the Court; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to strike a statement of claim, on the ground that it discloses no reasonable cause of action.

Subsection.Text: A motion may be brought at any time

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to remove an action from the operation of rules 294 to 299;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the release of arrested property in an action in rem; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for a default judgment.

Subsection.Text: In the trial of a simplified action, unless the Court directs otherwise, the evidence of each party shall be adduced by affidavit, which shall, subject to subsections (1.1) and (1.2), be served and filed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of evidence of a plaintiff, at least 20 days before the trial; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of evidence of a defendant, at least 10 days before the trial.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, no evidence in chief of an expert witness is admissible at the trial of an action in respect of any issue unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the issue has been defined by the pleadings or in an order made under rule 265;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an affidavit or statement of the expert witness prepared in accordance with rule 52.2 has been served on all other parties at least 60 days before the commencement of the trial; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the expert witness is available at the trial for cross-examination.

Subsection.Text: Except with leave of the Court, no expert witness’s evidence to rebut evidence in an affidavit or statement served under paragraph (1.1)(b) is admissible unless an affidavit or statement of the expert witness prepared in accordance with rule 52.2 has been served on all other parties at least 30 days before the commencement of the trial.
Unless all adverse parties agree otherwise, a witness whose affidavit evidence is tendered at trial shall be made available for cross-examination at trial.
Reply evidence, including that of an expert witness, may be provided orally at trial.

Section.Text: This Part applies to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: applications for judicial review of administrative action, including applications under section 18.1 or 28 of the Act, unless the Court directs under subsection 18.4(2) of the Act that the application be treated and proceeded with as an action;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: proceedings required or permitted by or under an Act of Parliament to be brought by application, motion, originating notice of motion, originating summons or petition or to be determined in a summary way, other than applications under subsection 33(1) of the Marine Liability Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: appeals under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: appeals under section 56 of the Trade-marks Act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: references from a tribunal under rule 320;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: requests under the Commercial Arbitration Code brought pursuant to subsection 324(1);

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: proceedings transferred to the Court under subsection 3(3) or 5(3) of the Divorce Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: applications for registration, recognition or enforcement of a foreign judgment brought under rules 327 to 334.

Section.Text: An application shall be commenced by a notice of application in Form 301, setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the court to which the application is addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the applicant and respondent;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the application is an application for judicial review,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the tribunal in respect of which the application is made, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and details of any order in respect of which judicial review is sought and the date on which it was first communicated to the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a precise statement of the relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a complete and concise statement of the grounds intended to be argued, including a reference to any statutory provision or rule to be relied on; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the documentary evidence to be used at the hearing of the application.

Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, an application for judicial review shall be limited to a single order in respect of which relief is sought.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), an applicant shall name as a respondent every person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: directly affected by the order sought in the application, other than a tribunal in respect of which the application is brought; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: required to be named as a party under an Act of Parliament pursuant to which the application is brought.

Subsection.Text: Where in an application for judicial review there are no persons that can be named under subsection (1), the applicant shall name the Attorney General of Canada as a respondent.

On a motion by the Attorney General of Canada, where the Court is satisfied that the Attorney General is unable or unwilling to act as a respondent after having been named under subsection (2), the Court may substitute another person or body, including the tribunal in respect of which the application is made, as a respondent in the place of the Attorney General of Canada.
Unless the Court directs otherwise, within 10 days after the issuance of a notice of application, the applicant shall serve it on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all respondents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of an application for judicial review or an application appealing the order of a tribunal,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of an application other than one relating to a decision of a visa officer, the tribunal in respect of which the application is brought,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other person who participated in the proceeding before the tribunal in respect of which the application is made, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Attorney General of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the application is made under the Access to Information Act, Part 1 of the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act, the Privacy Act or the Official Languages Act, the Commissioner named for the purposes of that Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other person required to be served under an Act of Parliament pursuant to which the application is brought.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Motion for directions as to service
Subsection.Text: Where there is any uncertainty as to who are the appropriate persons to be served with a notice of application, the applicant may bring an ex parte motion for directions to the Court.
Proof of service of a notice of application shall be filed within 10 days after service of the notice of application.

Section.Text: A respondent who intends to appear in respect of an application shall, within 10 days after being served with a notice of application, serve and file a notice of appearance in Form 305.

Within 30 days after issuance of a notice of application, an applicant shall serve its supporting affidavits and documentary exhibits and file proof of service. The affidavits and exhibits are deemed to be filed when the proof of service is filed in the Registry.

Within 30 days after service of the applicant’s affidavits, a respondent shall serve its supporting affidavits and documentary exhibits and shall file proof of service. The affidavits and exhibits are deemed to be filed when the proof of service is filed in the Registry.
Cross-examination on affidavits must be completed by all parties within 20 days after the filing of the respondent's affidavits or the expiration of the time for doing so, whichever is earlier.

Subsection.Text: An applicant shall serve and file the applicant’s record within 20 days after the day on which the parties’ cross-examinations are completed or within 20 days after the day on which the time for those cross-examinations is expired, whichever day is earlier.
The applicant shall file

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the application is brought in the Federal Court, an electronic copy of or three paper copies of the record; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the application is brought in the Federal Court of Appeal, an electronic copy of or five paper copies of the record.

Subsection.Text: An applicant's record shall contain, on consecutively numbered pages and in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents giving the nature and date of each document in the record;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the notice of application;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any order in respect of which the application is made and any reasons, including dissenting reasons, given in respect of that order;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: each supporting affidavit and documentary exhibit;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the transcript of any cross-examination on affidavits that the applicant has conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (e.1)
Paragraph.Text: any material that has been certified by a tribunal and transmitted under Rule 318 that is to be used by the applicant at the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the portions of any transcript of oral evidence before a tribunal that are to be used by the applicant at the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any physical exhibits to be used by the applicant at the hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant's memorandum of fact and law.

Subsection.Text: If an original affidavit is not filed as part of an applicant’s record, it shall be retained by the applicant for one year after the expiry of all appeal periods.
A respondent to an application shall, within 20 days after service of the applicant’s record, serve and file the respondent’s record.
The respondent shall file

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the application is brought in the Federal Court, an electronic copy of or three paper copies of the record; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the application is brought in the Federal Court of Appeal, an electronic copy of or five paper copies of the record.

Subsection.Text: The record of a respondent shall contain, on consecutively numbered pages and in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents giving the nature and date of each document in the record;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each supporting affidavit and documentary exhibit;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the transcript of any cross-examination on affidavits that the respondent has conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: any material that has been certified by a tribunal and transmitted under Rule 318 that is to be used by the respondent at the hearing and that is not contained in the applicant’s record;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the portions of any transcript of oral evidence before a tribunal that are to be used by the respondent at the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any physical exhibits to be used by the respondent at the hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the respondent's memorandum of fact and law.

Subsection.Text: If an original affidavit is not filed as part of a respondent’s record, it shall be retained by the respondent for one year after the expiry of all appeal periods.
On motion, the Court may order the Administrator to prepare a record on a party's behalf.
A party bringing a motion for an order under subsection (1) shall provide the Administrator with the documents referred to in subsection 309(2) or 310(2), as the case may be.

Section.Text: With leave of the Court, a party may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: file affidavits additional to those provided for in rules 306 and 307;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conduct cross-examinations on affidavits additional to those provided for in rule 308; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: file a supplementary record.

Section.Text: Where the Court considers that the application records of the parties are incomplete, the Court may order that other material, including any portion of a transcript, be filed.

Subsection.Text: An applicant shall, within 10 days after service of the respondent's record or the expiration of the time for doing so, whichever is earlier, serve and file a requisition, in Form 314, requesting that a date be set for the hearing of the application.
A requisition referred to in subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: include a statement that the requirements of subsection 309(1) have been satisfied and that any notice required under section 57 of the Act has been given;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set out the place at which the hearing should be held;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set out the maximum number of hours or days required for the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: list any dates within the following 90 days on which the parties are not available for a hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: set out the name, address, telephone number and fax number of the solicitor for every party to the application or, where a party is not represented by a solicitor, the person's name, address, telephone number and any fax number; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: indicate whether the hearing will be in English or French, or partly in English and partly in French.

Section.Text: The Court may order that a conference be held in accordance with rules 258 to 267, with such modifications as are necessary.
On motion, the Court may, in special circumstances, authorize a witness to testify in court in relation to an issue of fact raised in an application.
Despite rules 304, 306, 309 and 314, for a proceeding referred to in paragraph 300(b) that is brought ex parte,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the notice of application, the applicant’s record, affidavits and documentary exhibits and the requisition for hearing are not required to be served; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s record and the requisition for hearing must be filed at the time the notice of application is filed.

Section.MarginalNote: Summary application under Income Tax Act

Subsection.Text: Except for rule 359, the procedures set out in Part 7 apply, with any modifications that are required, to a summary application brought under section 231.7 of the Income Tax Act.
The application shall be commenced by a notice of summary application in Form 316.2.

Heading.TitleText: Material in the Possession of a Tribunal

Subsection.Text: A party may request material relevant to an application that is in the possession of a tribunal whose order is the subject of the application and not in the possession of the party by serving on the tribunal and filing a written request, identifying the material requested.
An applicant may include a request under subsection (1) in its notice of application.
If an applicant does not include a request under subsection (1) in its notice of application, the applicant shall serve the request on the other parties.
Within 20 days after service of a request under rule 317, the tribunal shall transmit

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a certified copy of the requested material to the Registry and to the party making the request; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the material cannot be reproduced, the original material to the Registry.

Subsection.Text: Where a tribunal or party objects to a request under rule 317, the tribunal or the party shall inform all parties and the Administrator, in writing, of the reasons for the objection.
The Court may give directions to the parties and to a tribunal as to the procedure for making submissions with respect to an objection under subsection (2).

The Court may, after hearing submissions with respect to an objection under subsection (2), order that a certified copy, or the original, of all or part of the material requested be forwarded to the Registry.

Section.Text: Unless the Court directs otherwise, after an application has been heard, the Administrator shall return to a tribunal any original material received from it under rule 318.

Subsection.Text: In rules 321 to 323, reference means a reference to the Court made by a tribunal or by the Attorney General of Canada under section 18.3 of the Act.
Subject to rules 321 to 323, rules 309 to 311 apply to references.

Section.Text: A notice of application in respect of a reference shall set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the court to which the application is addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the applicant; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the question being referred.

Section.Text: Where the Attorney General of Canada or a tribunal makes a reference, the Attorney General or tribunal shall bring an ex parte motion for directions as to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: which persons shall be given notice of the reference;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the material that will constitute the case to be determined on the reference;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the preparation, filing and service of copies of the material;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the preparation, filing and service of memoranda of fact and law;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the procedure for the hearing of the reference;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the time and place for the hearing of the reference; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the role, if any, of the tribunal in question.

Section.MarginalNote: Notice of intention to become party
Section.Text: Any of the following persons may become a party to a reference by serving and filing a notice of intention to participate in Form 323:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Attorney General of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the attorney general of a province, for the purpose of adducing evidence or making submissions to the Court under subsection 57(4) of the Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person who participated in the proceeding before the tribunal in respect of which the reference is made.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a request under the Commercial Arbitration Code, set out in Schedule 1 to the Commercial Arbitration Act, shall be brought by a notice of application.

Where the subject matter of an arbitration to which a request under the Code relates is already the subject matter of a proceeding before the Court, the request may be brought as a motion in that proceeding.
An affidavit in support of a notice of application under subsection (1) or a motion under subsection (2) shall be accompanied by a copy of the parties' arbitration agreement and state

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all material facts;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: unless the request is brought pursuant to article 8(1) or 9 of the Code, that the arbitration to which the request relates is governed by Canadian law or has been, is being or will be held within the jurisdiction of the Court; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the request is brought pursuant to article 27 of the Code, the nature of the evidence to be obtained, the name and address of any person to be heard as a witness and the subject-matter of any testimony required from that person, and describe any document to be produced or property to be inspected.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, where the Court makes a direction pursuant to subsection 3(3) or 5(3) of the Divorce Act, the rules made under section 25 of that Act for the province specified in the direction pursuant to subsection 23(2) of that Act shall apply to the conduct of the proceeding in the Court, with such modifications as the circumstances require.
A party to a proceeding referred to in subsection (1) may at any time, by motion, request a modification to the rules referred to in that subsection.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply to rules 327 to 334.

Definition.Text: arbitration agreement means an agreement in writing as defined in article II of the convention set out in the schedule to the United Nations Foreign Arbitral Awards Convention Act or an arbitration agreement as defined in Article 7 of the Commercial Arbitration Code, set out in Schedule 1 to the Commercial Arbitration Act.
foreign judgment means a judgment or arbitral award that may be registered in a court in Canada in accordance with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sections 63 to 71 of the Marine Liability Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Canada-United Kingdom Civil and Commercial Judgments Convention Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the United Nations Foreign Arbitral Awards Convention Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: articles 35 and 36 of the Commercial Arbitration Code, set out in Schedule 1 to the Commercial Arbitration Act.

Section.Text: An application for registration, recognition or enforcement of a foreign judgment shall be in Form 327.

Subsection.Text: An application under rule 327 may be brought ex parte.

On an ex parte application under subsection (1), the Court may direct that notice of the application be served on the foreign judgment debtor and may give such directions respecting the manner of service as it considers just.

An affidavit filed in an application under rule 327 shall be accompanied by an exemplified or certified copy of the foreign judgment, any reasons, including dissenting reasons, given in respect of that judgment and a copy of any arbitration agreement under which the judgment was awarded and shall state

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the foreign judgment was not fully satisfied as at the filing of the application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether the foreign judgment debtor appeared in the original proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an address in Canada for service on the foreign judgment creditor;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name and usual or last known address of the foreign judgment debtor;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether interest has accrued on the amount payable under the foreign judgment in accordance with the law of the state of the originating court or arbitral tribunal and, if interest has accrued, the rate of interest, the day from which it is payable, the amount due at the time of the filing of the application and, where applicable, the day on which interest ceases to accrue;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the rate of exchange into Canadian currency prevailing on the day on which the foreign judgment was rendered, as ascertained from a chartered bank in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: that, having made careful and full inquiries, the applicant knows of no impediment to registration, recognition or enforcement of the foreign judgment; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: that the foreign judgment is executory, that no appeal or other form of judicial review is pending and that any time prescribed for the making of an appeal or application for judicial review has expired.

Subsection.Text: Where a foreign judgment debtor did not appear in the original proceeding, an affidavit referred to in subsection (1) shall be accompanied by an affidavit of service on the foreign judgment debtor of the document instituting the original proceedings.

Section.Text: The Court may accept evidence on an application under rule 327 other than affidavit evidence.

Unless the Court orders otherwise, an amount payable under a foreign judgment shall be converted into the equivalent amount in Canadian currency on the basis of the rate of exchange, ascertained from a chartered bank in Canada, that was prevailing on the day on which the foreign judgment was rendered.

Subsection.Text: Any interest on an amount payable under a foreign judgment that has accrued to the day of registration of the foreign judgment shall be added to the amount payable under the foreign judgment.

Unless the Court orders otherwise, an amount payable under a foreign judgment registered pursuant to an application under rule 327 bears interest from the day of registration at the rate set out in section 3 of the Interest Act.

Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, a foreign judgment creditor who obtains an order for registration of a foreign judgment shall personally serve the order on the foreign judgment debtor, together with a translation thereof in the language of the foreign judgment and an affidavit attesting to its accuracy.

Unless the Court orders otherwise, execution shall not be issued on a foreign judgment registered pursuant to an application under rule 327 until proof of service of the order for registration has been filed.
This Part applies to actions and applications other than applications for judicial review under section 28 of the Act.

Section.MarginalNote: Applicability of rules for actions and applications
Section.Text: Except to the extent that they are incompatible with the rules in this Part, the rules applicable to actions and applications, as the case may be, apply to class proceedings.

Heading.TitleText: Proceedings That May Be Certified as Class Proceedings

Subsection.Text: Despite rule 302, a member of a class of persons may commence an action or an application on behalf of the members of that class, in which case the originating document shall be prefaced by the heading “Proposed Class Proceeding”.
The member shall bring a motion for the certification of the proceeding as a class proceeding and for the appointment of the member as representative plaintiff or applicant.
The representative of a class shall be a person who may act as a plaintiff or an applicant under these Rules.

For the purposes of subsection (1), in the case of an application for judicial review referred to in section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, the originating document is the application for leave referred to in subsection 72(1) of that Act.

A defendant to an action or a respondent to an application may, at any time, bring a motion for the certification of the proceeding as a class proceeding and for the appointment of a representative plaintiff or applicant.

Rule 334.16 applies to the certification of a proceeding referred to in subsection (1) as a class proceeding, with the exception, unless a judge orders otherwise, of subparagraphs 334.16(1)(e)(ii) and (iv) and paragraphs 334.16(3)(b) and (d).

If a defendant to an action that was commenced by a member of a class of persons on behalf of the members of that class makes a counterclaim against the class, the counterclaim may not proceed unless it is certified as a class proceeding.

A party to an action or an application against two or more defendants or respondents may, at any time, bring a motion for the certification of the proceeding as a class proceeding and for the appointment of a representative defendant or respondent.
This Part applies, with any necessary modifications, to a counterclaim referred to in subsection (1) and to a proceeding referred to in subsection (2).
A notice of motion for the certification of a proceeding as a class proceeding and the affidavit in support of that motion shall be served and filed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in an application for judicial review referred to in section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, at the time fixed by the case management judge assigned to the proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other proceeding, at least 14 days before the day set out in the notice for the hearing of the motion.

Subsection.Text: In the case of an action, the motion shall be made returnable no later than 90 days after the later of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the last statement of defence was filed, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which, under rule 204, the last statement of defence is required to be served and filed.

Subsection.Text: In the case of an application, the motion shall be made returnable

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in an application for judicial review referred to in section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, at the time fixed by the case management judge assigned to the proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other application, no later than 30 days after the issuance of the notice of application.

Subsection.Text: A person who serves and files an affidavit in response to a notice of motion and affidavit shall serve and file it at least five days before the day set out in the notice for the hearing of the motion.
A person filing an affidavit under subsection (1) or (4) shall set out in the affidavit

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the material facts on which the person intends to rely at the hearing of the motion;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that the person knows of no fact material to the motion that has not been disclosed in the person’s affidavit; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to the best of the person’s knowledge, the number of members in the proposed class.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), a judge shall, by order, certify a proceeding as a class proceeding if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pleadings disclose a reasonable cause of action;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is an identifiable class of two or more persons;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claims of the class members raise common questions of law or fact, whether or not those common questions predominate over questions affecting only individual members;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a class proceeding is the preferable procedure for the just and efficient resolution of the common questions of law or fact; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: there is a representative plaintiff or applicant who

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: would fairly and adequately represent the interests of the class,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has prepared a plan for the proceeding that sets out a workable method of advancing the proceeding on behalf of the class and of notifying class members as to how the proceeding is progressing,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: does not have, on the common questions of law or fact, an interest that is in conflict with the interests of other class members, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: provides a summary of any agreements respecting fees and disbursements between the representative plaintiff or applicant and the solicitor of record.

Subsection.Text: All relevant matters shall be considered in a determination of whether a class proceeding is the preferable procedure for the just and efficient resolution of the common questions of law or fact, including whether

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the questions of law or fact common to the class members predominate over any questions affecting only individual members;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a significant number of the members of the class have a valid interest in individually controlling the prosecution of separate proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the class proceeding would involve claims that are or have been the subject of any other proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: other means of resolving the claims are less practical or less efficient; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the administration of the class proceeding would create greater difficulties than those likely to be experienced if relief were sought by other means.

Subsection.Text: If the judge determines that a class includes a subclass whose members have claims that raise common questions of law or fact that are not shared by all of the class members so that the protection of the interests of the subclass members requires that they be separately represented, the judge shall not certify the proceeding as a class proceeding unless there is a representative plaintiff or applicant who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: would fairly and adequately represent the interests of the subclass;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has prepared a plan for the proceeding that sets out a workable method of advancing the proceeding on behalf of the subclass and of notifying subclass members as to how the proceeding is progressing;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not have, on the common questions of law or fact for the subclass, an interest that is in conflict with the interests of other subclass members; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provides a summary of any agreements respecting fees and disbursements between the representative plaintiff or applicant and the solicitor of record.

Subsection.Text: An order certifying a proceeding as a class proceeding shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: describe the class;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: state the name of the representative plaintiff or applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: state the nature of the claims made on behalf of the class;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: state the relief claimed by or from the class;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: set out the common questions of law or fact for the class; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: specify the time and manner for class members to opt out of the class proceeding.

Subsection.Text: If the judge determines that a class includes a subclass whose members have claims that raise common questions of law or fact that are not shared by all of the class members so that the protection of the interests of the subclass members requires that they be separately represented, the certifying order shall include the information referred to in subsection (1) in respect of the subclass.

Section.MarginalNote: Grounds that may not be relied on
Section.Text: A judge shall not refuse to certify a proceeding as a class proceeding solely on one or more of the following grounds:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the relief claimed includes a claim for damages that would require an individual assessment after a determination of the common questions of law or fact;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the relief claimed relates to separate contracts involving different class members;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: different remedies are sought for different class members;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the precise number of class members or the identity of each class member is not known; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the class includes a subclass whose members have claims that raise common questions of law or fact not shared by all of the class members.

Section.Text: A judge may, on motion, amend an order certifying a proceeding as a class proceeding or, if the conditions for certification are no longer satisfied with respect to the proceeding, decertify it.

If a judge refuses to certify a proceeding as a class proceeding or decertifies a proceeding, the judge may permit the proceeding to continue as one or more proceedings and may make any appropriate order in that regard.

Subsection.Text: A class member involved in a class proceeding may opt out of the proceeding within the time and in the manner specified in the order certifying the proceeding as a class proceeding.

A class member shall be excluded from the class proceeding if the member does not, before the expiry of the time for opting out specified in the certifying order, discontinue a proceeding brought by the member that raises the common questions of law or fact set out in that order.

A party in an action that has been certified as a class proceeding may examine a class member, other than the representative plaintiff, for discovery only on leave granted by the Court and only after the examination of the representative plaintiff.
In deciding whether to grant leave to examine class members, the Court shall consider all relevant matters, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the stage of the class proceeding and the issues to be determined at that stage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the presence of subclasses;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the necessity of an examination in view of the claims or defences of the party seeking leave;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the approximate monetary value of any individual claims; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility that the examination might result in undue burden or expense for the class members sought to be examined.

Subsection.Text: A class member is subject to the same sanctions under these Rules as a party for failure to submit to an examination.
To ensure the fair and adequate representation of the interests of a class or any subclass, the Court may, at any time, permit one or more class members to participate in the class proceeding.

When permitting a class member to participate in the proceeding, the Court shall give directions regarding the role of the participant, including matters relating to costs and to the procedures to be followed.
A judge may give a single judgment in respect of the common questions of law or fact and separate judgments in respect of any other questions.
A judgment on questions of law or fact that are common to a class or subclass shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out the common questions of law or fact;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: name or describe the class or subclass members to the extent possible;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: state the nature of the claims asserted on behalf of the class or subclass; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: specify the relief granted.

Subsection.Text: A judgment on questions of law or fact that are common to a class or subclass binds every class or subclass member who has not opted out of or been excluded from the class proceeding, but only to the extent that the judgment determines common questions of law or fact that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are set out in the certifying order;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: relate to claims described in that order; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: relate to relief sought by the class or subclass as stated in that order.

Subsection.Text: A judgment on common questions of law or fact of a class or subclass does not bind a party to the class proceeding in any subsequent proceeding between the party and a member who has opted out of or been excluded from the class proceeding.

If a judge determines that there are questions of law or fact that apply only to certain individual class or subclass members, the judge shall set a time within which those members may make claims in respect of those questions and may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: order that the individual questions be determined in further hearings;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: appoint one or more persons to evaluate the individual questions and report back to the judge; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: direct the manner in which the individual questions will be determined.

Subsection.Text: In those circumstances, the judge may give directions relating to the procedures to be followed.

For the purposes of paragraph (1)(a), the judge who determined the common questions of law or fact, another judge or, in the case of a claim referred to in subsection 50(3), a prothonotary may preside over the hearings of the individual questions.

Section.Text: In the case of an action, if, after determining common questions of law or fact in favour of a class or subclass, a judge determines that the defendant’s liability to individual class members cannot be determined without proof by those individual class members, rule 334.26 applies to the determination of the defendant’s liability to those class members.

Subsection.Text: A judge may make any order in respect of the assessment of monetary relief, including aggregate assessments, that is due to the class or subclass.
A judge may make any order in respect of the distribution of monetary relief, including an undistributed portion of an award that is due to a class or subclass or its members.
For the purposes of this rule, a judge may order any special modes of proof.
A class proceeding may be settled only with the approval of a judge.
On approval, a settlement binds every class or subclass member who has not opted out of or been excluded from the class proceeding.

Section.Text: A proceeding commenced by a member of a class of persons on behalf of the members of that class may only be discontinued with the approval of a judge.

Subsection.Text: A class member may appeal any order determining or dismissing the member’s claim in respect of one or more individual questions.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Representative plaintiff or applicant failing to appeal
Subsection.Text: If a representative plaintiff or applicant does not appeal an order, or does appeal and later files a notice of discontinuance of the appeal, any member of the class for which the representative plaintiff or applicant had been appointed may apply for leave to exercise the right of appeal of that representative within 30 days after

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the expiry of the appeal period available to the representative, if the representative does not appeal; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the notice of discontinuance is filed, if the representative appeals and later files a notice of discontinuance of the appeal.

Subsection.Text: Notice that a proceeding has been certified as a class proceeding shall be given by the representative plaintiff or applicant to the class members.
A judge may dispense with the giving of notice after considering the factors set out in subsection (3).
A judge shall order when and by what means notice is to be given after considering the following factors:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of giving notice;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the size of the individual claims of the class members;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number of class members;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the presence of subclasses;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the likelihood that some or all of the class members will opt out of the class proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the places of residence of class members.

Subsection.Text: The order may provide that notice be given by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: personal delivery;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: mail;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: posting, publishing, advertising or the distribution of leaflets;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: individually notifying a sample group within the class; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other appropriate means or combination of appropriate means.

Subsection.Text: The notice shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: describe the proceeding, including the names and addresses of the representative plaintiff or applicant, and the relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: state the time and manner for a class member to opt out of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: describe the possible financial consequences of the proceeding to the class and subclass members;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: summarize any agreements respecting fees and disbursements

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: between the representative plaintiff or applicant and that representative’s solicitor, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the recipient of the notice is a member of a subclass, between the representative plaintiff or applicant for that subclass and that representative’s solicitor;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an action, describe any counterclaim being asserted by or against the class or any subclass, including the relief sought in the counterclaim;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: state that the judgment on the common questions of law or fact for the class or subclass, whether favourable or not, will bind all of the class members or subclass members who do not opt out of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: describe the right, if any, of the class or subclass members to participate in the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: give an address to which class members may direct inquiries about the proceeding.

Subsection.Text: With leave of the judge, the notice may include a solicitation of contributions from the class or subclass members to assist in paying the fees and disbursements of the solicitor of record.

Section.MarginalNote: Notice of determination of common questions
Section.Text: If common questions of law or fact are determined in favour of the class or a subclass, the representative plaintiff or applicant for the class or subclass shall give notice of that determination to the class or subclass members in accordance with the directions of a judge in respect of the content of and means of giving the notice.

Notice that an offer to settle has been made or that a settlement has been approved under rule 334.29 shall be given by the representative plaintiff or applicant to the class or subclass members in accordance with the directions of a judge in respect of the content of and means of giving the notice.

Subsection.Text: A judge may, at any time, order any party to give any notice that the judge considers necessary to protect the interests of any class member or party or to ensure the fair conduct of the proceeding.
Subsections 334.32(3) and (4) apply to a notice given under this rule.

Section.Text: A judge may order any party to give a notice under rules 334.32 to 334.35.
Notices referred to in rules 334.32 to 334.35 shall not be given unless they have been approved by a judge.
The judge has full discretion over the amount and allocation of expenses in respect of notices and may determine who is to pay those expenses.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no costs may be awarded against any party to a motion for certification of a proceeding as a class proceeding, to a class proceeding or to an appeal arising from a class proceeding, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of the party unnecessarily lengthened the duration of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any step in the proceeding by the party was improper, vexatious or unnecessary or was taken through negligence, mistake or excessive caution; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: exceptional circumstances make it unjust to deprive the successful party of costs.

Subsection.Text: The Court has full discretion to award costs with respect to the determination of the individual claims of a class member.

Section.Text: No payments, including indirect payments, shall be made to a solicitor from the proceeds recovered in a class proceeding unless the payments are approved by a judge.
This Part applies to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appeals to the Federal Court of Appeal from the Federal Court, including appeals from interlocutory orders;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: appeals to the Federal Court of Appeal from the Tax Court of Canada under subsections 27(1.1) and (1.2) of the Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: appeals to the Court under an Act of Parliament, unless otherwise indicated in that Act or these Rules.

Section.Text: In this Part, first instance means a proceeding in the Federal Court, the Tax Court of Canada or the tribunal whose order is being appealed.

Section.MarginalNote: Content of general notice of appeal
Section.Text: An appeal, other than an appeal from a final judgment of the Tax Court of Canada under subsection 27(1.2) of the Act, shall be commenced by a notice of appeal, in Form 337, setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the court to which the appeal is taken;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the parties;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a precise statement of the relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a complete and concise statement of the grounds intended to be argued, including a reference to any statutory provision or rule to be relied on;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the court or tribunal appealed from;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date and details of the order under appeal; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the place proposed for the hearing of the appeal.

Section.MarginalNote: Content of notice of appeal — certain judgments of Tax Court of Canada
Section.Text: An appeal from a final judgment of the Tax Court of Canada under subsection 27(1.2) of the Act shall be commenced by a notice of appeal, in Form 337.1, setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the parties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a precise statement of the relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a complete and concise statement of the grounds intended to be argued, including a reference to any statutory provision or rule to be relied on;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date and details of the final judgment under appeal; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the place proposed for the hearing of the appeal.

Section.MarginalNote: Persons to be included as respondents

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, an appellant shall include as a respondent in an appeal

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every party in the first instance who is adverse in interest to the appellant in the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other person required to be named as a party by an Act of Parliament pursuant to which the appeal is brought; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where there are no persons that are included under paragraph (a) or (b), the Attorney General of Canada.

Subsection.Text: On a motion by the Attorney General of Canada, where the Court is satisfied that the Attorney General is unable or unwilling to act as a respondent in an appeal, the Court may substitute another person or body, including a tribunal whose order is being appealed, as a respondent in the place of the Attorney General of Canada.
Unless the Court directs otherwise or an Act of Parliament authorizing the appeal provides otherwise, within 10 days after the issuance of a notice of appeal, the appellant shall serve it on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all respondents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an appeal of an order of a tribunal,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the Attorney General of Canada, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the tribunal or its chief executive officer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any person who is not a party and who participated in the first instance; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other person directly affected by the appeal.

Subsection.Text: Proof of service of a notice of appeal shall be filed within 10 days after the notice of appeal is served.

Section.MarginalNote: Solicitor of record and address for service
Section.Text: In an appeal from the Federal Court to the Federal Court of Appeal, the solicitor of record and the address for service of a party on the appeal shall be the same as they were in the first instance.

Subsection.Text: A respondent who intends to participate in an appeal shall, within 10 days after service of the notice of appeal, serve and file

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a notice of appearance in Form 341A; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the respondent seeks a different disposition of the order appealed from, a notice of cross-appeal in Form 341B.

Subsection.Text: A notice of cross-appeal shall set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a precise statement of the relief sought; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a complete and concise statement of the grounds intended to be argued, including a reference to any statutory provision or rule to be relied on.

Subsection.Text: Where a respondent has not filed a notice of cross-appeal under subsection (1), the cross-appeal may not be heard without leave of the Court.
Unless the Court orders otherwise, where more than one party appeals from an order, all appeals shall be consolidated.
The Court may give directions as to the procedure to be followed in a consolidation under subsection (1).

Within 30 days after the filing of a notice of appeal, the parties shall agree in writing as to the documents, exhibits and transcripts to be included in the appeal book and shall file a copy of that agreement.
The parties shall include in an appeal book only such documents, exhibits and transcripts as are required to dispose of the issues on appeal.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Motion to determine content of appeal book
Subsection.Text: If no agreement is reached within the period referred to in subsection (1), the appellant shall, within 10 days after the expiration of that period, serve and file a notice of motion under rule 369 to request that the Court determine the content of the appeal book.

Where a transcript or the reproduction of exhibits is required, the appellant shall order it and shall file proof of the order within 10 days after filing an agreement under subsection (1) or obtaining an order under subsection (3).

The appeal book shall be prepared by the appellant forthwith unless, on the motion of the appellant, the Court orders the Administrator to prepare an appeal book on the appellant's behalf from documents provided by the appellant.
An appeal book shall contain, on consecutively numbered pages and in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents describing each document;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the notice of appeal and any notice of cross-appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the order appealed from, as signed and entered, and any reasons, including dissenting reasons, given in respect of that order;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the originating document, any other pleadings and any other document in the first instance that defines the issues in the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), all documents, exhibits and transcripts agreed on under subsection 343(1) or ordered to be included on a motion under subsection 343(3);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any order made in respect of the conduct of the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other document relevant to the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: an agreement reached under subsection 343(1) as to the contents of the appeal book or an order made under subsection 343(3); and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate in Form 344, signed by the appellant's solicitor, stating that the contents of the appeal book are complete and legible.

Subsection.Text: An appeal book that is filed in paper copy shall have a grey cover.
Transcripts may be reproduced in a separate document.
An appellant shall serve and file the appeal book within 30 days after the day on which a copy of an agreement under subsection 343(1) is filed or an order under subsection 343(3) is obtained.
The appellant shall file

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the appeal is brought in the Federal Court, an electronic copy of or three paper copies of the book; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the appeal is brought in the Federal Court of Appeal, an electronic copy of or five paper copies of the book.

Subsection.Text: Within 30 days after filing an appeal book, the appellant shall serve and file a memorandum of fact and law.
Within 30 days after service of the appellant's memorandum of fact and law, the respondent shall serve and file the respondent's memorandum of fact and law.
Where a respondent has served a notice of cross-appeal under rule 341,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the respondent shall serve and file a memorandum of fact and law as appellant by cross-appeal, as part of the respondent's memorandum of fact and law, within the time set out in subsection (2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant shall serve and file a memorandum of fact and law as respondent to cross-appeal, within 30 days after service of the respondent's memorandum of fact and law.

Subsection.Text: A memorandum of fact and law that is in paper copy shall have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the appellant’s memorandum, a beige cover;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the respondent’s memorandum, a green cover; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an intervener’s memorandum, a blue cover.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Number of memoranda to be filed
Subsection.Text: Memoranda of fact and law shall be filed in the same number as are appeal books.

Within 20 days after service of the respondent's memorandum of fact and law or 20 days after the expiration of the time for service of the respondent's memorandum of fact and law, whichever is the earlier, an appellant shall serve and file a requisition in Form 347 requesting that a date be set for the hearing of the appeal.

Where an appellant fails to comply with subsection (1), a respondent may, in lieu of bringing a motion under rule 167, serve and file a requisition in Form 347 to request that a date be set for the hearing of the appeal.
A requisition referred to in subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: include a statement that the requirements of subsections 346(1) and (5) have been satisfied and that any notice required under section 57 of the Act has been given;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set out the location at which the hearing should be held;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set out the maximum number of hours or days required for the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: list any dates within the following 90 days on which the parties are not available for a hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: set out the name, address, telephone number and fax number of the solicitor for every party to the appeal or, where a party is not represented by a solicitor, the person's name, address, telephone number and any fax number; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: indicate whether the hearing will be in English or French, or partly in English and partly in French.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), at least 30 days before the hearing date, the parties shall file

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the appeal is brought in the Federal Court, an electronic copy of or three paper copies of a joint book of statutes, regulations and authorities; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the appeal is brought in the Federal Court of Appeal, an electronic copy of or five paper copies of a joint book of statutes, regulations and authorities.

Subsection.Text: If the parties cannot agree on a joint book of statutes, regulations and authorities, they shall file separate books in lieu thereof, without reproducing documents included in the book of another party.
Extracts of federal statutes and regulations in a book of statutes, regulations and authorities shall be reproduced in both official languages.
A book of statutes, regulations and authorities that is in paper copy shall have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the book is filed jointly, a burgundy cover; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the book is filed separately, a cover that is the same colour as the filing party’s memorandum of fact and law.

Heading.TitleText: Consent to Reversal or Variation of Judgment

Section.MarginalNote: Consent to reversal or variation of judgment

Subsection.Text: A respondent may consent to the reversal or variation of an order appealed from by serving and filing a notice to that effect.
The Court may pronounce judgment in accordance with a notice filed under subsection (1) if the resultant judgment is one that could have been given on consent.

Heading.TitleText: Material in the Possession of a Tribunal

Section.MarginalNote: Material in possession of a tribunal
Section.Text: Rules 317 to 319 apply to appeals and motions for leave to appeal, with such modifications as are necessary.
In special circumstances, the Court may grant leave to a party to present evidence on a question of fact.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, where leave to appeal is required, it shall be obtained on a motion brought in writing.
On a motion under subsection (1) the moving party shall name as respondents all persons referred to in rule 338 and personally serve all persons referred to in rule 339.
Unless the Court orders otherwise, a party bringing a motion for leave to appeal shall serve the motion record and file an electronic copy of or three paper copies of that record.
A motion record referred to in subsection (1) shall contain, on consecutively numbered pages and in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the order in respect of which leave to appeal is sought and any reasons, including dissenting reasons, given in respect of that order;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pleadings and any other material that is necessary for the hearing of the motion;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an affidavit that sets out any facts relied on in the motion that do not appear on the Court file; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a memorandum of fact and law.

Section.MarginalNote: Respondent’s memorandum of fact and law
Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, a respondent to a motion for leave to appeal shall serve a memorandum of fact and law and any supporting affidavits and file an electronic copy of or three paper copies of each of them no later than 20 days after the day on which the motion record is served.

Unless the Court orders otherwise, a party bringing a motion for leave to appeal shall serve any reply to the respondent’s memorandum of fact and law and file an electronic copy of or three paper copies of the reply no later than 10 days after the day on which it is served.
On the filing of a reply under rule 355 or the expiration of the period allowed for a reply, the Court may dispose in writing of a motion for leave to appeal.

Heading.TitleText: Leave to Appeal to the Supreme Court of Canada

Section.MarginalNote: Motion for leave to appeal to Supreme Court

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding rule 352, where a judgment of the Federal Court of Appeal is delivered from the bench, a motion under section 37.1 of the Supreme Court Act for leave to appeal from the judgment to the Supreme Court of Canada may be made at the time the judgment is delivered and without prior notice.

A motion for leave to appeal under section 37.1 of the Supreme Court Act shall, unless the Court permits otherwise, be argued on the case, and on the reasons for judgment, from which leave to appeal is sought.
A motion for leave to appeal under section 37.1 of the Supreme Court Act shall be heard before not fewer than three judges, who need not be the judges who heard the matter under appeal.

Section.Text: This Part applies to motions other than motions for leave to appeal under Part 6.
Except with leave of the Court, a motion shall be initiated by a notice of motion, in Form 359, setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a motion other than one made under rule 369, the time, place and estimated duration of the hearing of the motion;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the grounds intended to be argued, including a reference to any statutory provision or rule to be relied on; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the documents or other material to be used at the hearing of the motion.

Section.Text: No notice of motion may be filed unless it is expressly made returnable

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at sittings fixed under rule 34;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at a time and place appointed under subsection 35(2); or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in writing, under rule 369.

Section.Text: Notwithstanding rules 362, 364, 367 and 370, a party bringing an ex parte motion need not comply with the service requirements set out in those rules.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), on a motion other than a motion under rule 369, a notice of motion and any affidavit required under rule 363 shall be served and filed at least three days before the day set out in the notice for the hearing of the motion.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Motion on less than three days notice
Subsection.Text: The Court may hear the motion on less than three days’ notice

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the motion is made on notice, if all parties consent; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any case, if the moving party satisfies the Court of the urgency of the motion.

Section.Text: A party to a motion shall set out in an affidavit any facts to be relied on by that party in the motion that do not appear on the Court file.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, a person bringing a motion shall serve a motion record and file an electronic copy of or three paper copies of that record.
A moving party's motion record shall contain, on consecutively numbered pages arranged in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the notice of motion;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all affidavits and other material served by the moving party for use on the motion;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to rule 368, the portions of any transcripts on which the moving party intends to rely;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: subject to rule 366, written representations; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any other filed material that is necessary for the hearing of the motion.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Service and filing of motion record
Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections 51(2), 163(2) and 213(3), on a motion other than a motion under rule 369, the motion record shall be served and filed at least three days before the day set out in the notice of motion for the hearing of the motion.

Subject to subsections 213(4) and 369(2), a respondent to a motion shall serve a respondent’s motion record and file an electronic copy of or three paper copies of the record no later than 2:00 p.m. on the day that is two days before the day fixed for the hearing of the motion.
The motion record of a respondent to a motion shall contain, on consecutively numbered pages and in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all affidavits and other material to be used by the respondent on the motion that is not included in the moving party's motion record;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to rule 368, the portions of any transcripts on which the respondent intends to rely;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to rule 366, written representations; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other filed material not contained in the moving party's motion record that is necessary for the hearing of the motion.

Section.MarginalNote: Memorandum of fact and law required
Section.Text: On a motion for summary judgment or summary trial, for an interlocutory injunction, for the determination of a question of law or for the certification of a proceeding as a class proceeding, or if the Court so orders, a motion record shall contain a memorandum of fact and law instead of written representations.

Section.MarginalNote: Documents filed as part of motion record
Section.Text: A notice of motion or any affidavit required to be filed by a party to a motion may be served and filed as part of the party's motion record and need not be served and filed separately.
Transcripts of all cross-examinations on affidavits on a motion shall be filed before the hearing of the motion.

Subsection.Text: A party may, in a notice of motion, request that the motion be decided on the basis of written representations.

A respondent to a motion brought in accordance with subsection (1) shall serve and file a respondent's record within 10 days after being served under rule 364 and, if the respondent objects to disposition of the motion in writing, indicate in its written representations or memorandum of fact and law the reasons why the motion should not be disposed of in writing.
A moving party may serve and file written representations in reply within four days after being served with a respondent's record under subsection (2).

On the filing of a reply under subsection (3) or on the expiration of the period allowed for a reply, the Court may dispose of a motion in writing or fix a time and place for an oral hearing of the motion.
A party who brings a motion may abandon it by serving and filing a notice of abandonment in Form 370.
Where a moving party fails to appear at the hearing of a motion without serving and filing a notice of abandonment, it is deemed to have abandoned the motion.

Section.Text: On motion, the Court may, in special circumstances, authorize a witness to testify in court in relation to an issue of fact raised on a motion.

Subsection.Text: A motion under this Part may not be brought before the commencement of a proceeding except in a case of urgency.
A party bringing a motion before the commencement of a proceeding shall undertake to commence the proceeding within the time fixed by the Court.
On motion, a judge may grant an interlocutory injunction.

Unless a judge orders otherwise, a party bringing a motion for an interlocutory injunction shall undertake to abide by any order concerning damages caused by the granting or extension of the injunction.
Where it appears to a judge that the issues in a motion for an interlocutory injunction should be decided by an expedited hearing of the proceeding, the judge may make an order under rule 385.
A judge may order that any evidence submitted at the hearing of a motion for an interlocutory injunction shall be considered as evidence submitted at the hearing of the proceeding.
A judge may grant an interim injunction on an ex parte motion for a period of not more than 14 days where the judge is satisfied

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a case of urgency, that no notice is possible; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that to give notice would defeat the purpose of the motion.

Subsection.Text: A motion to extend an interim injunction that was granted on an ex parte motion may be brought only on notice to every party affected by the injunction, unless the moving party can demonstrate that a party has been evading service or that there are other sufficient reasons to extend the interim injunction without notice to the party.
Where a motion to extend an interim injunction under subsection (2) is brought ex parte, the extension may be granted for a further period of not more than 14 days.
On motion, a judge may appoint a receiver in any proceeding.
An order under subsection (1) shall set out the remuneration to be paid to, and the amount of security to be given by, the receiver.

Section.Text: A receiver appointed under rule 375 shall, by motion to the Court, seek approval of the receiver's accounts on an annual basis.

Section.MarginalNote: Motion for order in respect of property

Subsection.Text: On motion, the Court may make an order for the custody or preservation of property that is, or will be, the subject-matter of a proceeding or as to which a question may arise therein.
Rule 374 applies to interim orders for the custody or preservation of property referred to in subsection (1), with such modifications as the circumstances require.
An order under subsection 377(1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identify the property to be kept or preserved;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: state where, by whom, for how long and at whose cost the property is to be kept or preserved; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the property is to be insured, state at whose expense it shall be insured.

Subsection.Text: An order under subsection 377(1) shall be directed solely to the protection of the property in question.

Section.MarginalNote: Sale of perishable or deteriorating property
Section.Text: Where any property, other than real property or immoveables, that is the subject-matter of a proceeding or the subject of a question that may arise in a proceeding

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is of a perishable nature,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is likely to deteriorate if kept, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: should for any other reason be sold without delay,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: on motion, the Court may order the sale of the property, in such a manner and on such conditions as may be specified in the order.

Heading.Label: PART 9
Heading.TitleText: Case Management and Dispute Resolution Services

Subsection.Text: If, in an action commenced in the Federal Court,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 180 days have elapsed since the issuance of the statement of claim and no statement of defence has been filed and no motion for default judgement is pending, the Administrator shall issue a notice of status review, in Form 380, to the parties; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 360 days have elapsed since the issuance of the statement of claim and no requisition for a pre-trial conference has been filed, the Court shall order that the action continue as a specially managed proceeding and may make an order under rule 385.

Subsection.Text: If, in an application commenced in the Federal Court, 180 days have elapsed since the issuance of the notice of application and no requisition for a hearing date has been filed, the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: issue a notice of status review, in Form 380, to the parties; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
