Paragraph.Text: order that the application continue as a specially managed proceeding and may make an order under rule 385.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to an action or an application continued as a specially managed proceeding or in respect of which a motion to continue the proceeding as a specially managed proceeding is pending.

Section.Text: If the Court orders that an action or an application continue as a specially managed proceeding under paragraph 380(1)(b) or (2)(b), and no order under rule 385 has been made in accordance with that paragraph, the plaintiff or applicant, within 20 days of the date of the order, shall serve and file a proposed timetable for the completion of the steps necessary to advance the proceeding in an expeditious manner.

Subsection.Text: If a notice of status review is issued in respect of an action or an application, the plaintiff or applicant, within 15 days of the date of the notice of status review, shall serve and file representations stating the reasons why the proceeding should not be dismissed for delay. The representations shall include a justification for the delay and a proposed timetable for the completion of the steps necessary to advance the proceeding in an expeditious manner.
The defendant or respondent may serve and file representations within seven days after being served with the representations of the plaintiff or applicant.
The plaintiff or applicant may serve and file a reply within four days after being served with the representations of the defendant or respondent.
Unless the Court directs otherwise, a status review of a proceeding commenced in the Federal Court shall be conducted on the basis of the written representations of the parties.
A judge or prothonotary shall conduct a status review and may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if he or she is not satisfied that the proceeding should continue, dismiss the proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if he or she is satisfied that the proceeding should continue, order that it continue as a specially managed proceeding and may make an order under rule 385.

Heading.TitleText: Status Review — Federal Court of Appeal

Section.MarginalNote: Application or appeal — Federal Court of Appeal
Section.Text: If, in an application or appeal commenced in the Federal Court of Appeal, 180 days have elapsed since the issuance of the notice of application or appeal and no requisition for a hearing date has been filed, the Court may issue a notice of status review in Form 382.2 to the parties.

Section.MarginalNote: Representations when applicant or appellant in default

Subsection.Text: If the party in default is the applicant or the appellant, that party, within 30 days after the issuance of the notice of status review, shall serve and file representations stating the reasons why the proceeding should not be dismissed for delay. The representations shall include a justification for the delay and a proposed timetable for the completion of the steps necessary to advance the proceeding in an expeditious manner.

If the party in default is the respondent, that party, within 30 days after the issuance of the notice of status review, shall serve and file representations stating the reasons why default judgment should not be entered. The representations shall include a justification for the delay and a proposed timetable for the completion of the steps necessary to advance the proceeding in an expeditious manner.
The other party may serve and file representations within 10 days after being served with the representations of the party that is in default.
In this rule and rule 382.4, party in default means the party that failed to take the next chronological step required by these Rules after the last step that was completed.
Unless the Court directs otherwise, a status review of a proceeding commenced in the Federal Court of Appeal shall be conducted on the basis of the written representations of the parties.
A judge shall conduct a status review and may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if he or she is not satisfied that the proceeding should continue and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the party in default is the applicant or the appellant, dismiss the proceeding, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the party in default is the respondent, grant judgment in favour of the applicant or appellant or order the applicant or appellant to proceed to prove entitlement to the judgment claimed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if he or she is satisfied that the proceeding should continue,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: give any directions that are necessary for the just, most expeditious and least expensive determination of the proceeding on its merits, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: fix the period for completion of subsequent steps in the proceeding.

Section.Text: The Chief Justice of the Federal Court may assign

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one or more judges to act as a case management judge in a proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one or more prothonotaries to act as a case management judge in a proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a prothonotary to assist in the management of a proceeding.

Section.MarginalNote: Case management judges — Federal Court of Appeal
Section.Text: The Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Appeal may assign one or more judges to act as a case management judge in a proceeding.
The Court may at any time order that a proceeding continue as a specially managed proceeding.
A proceeding commenced by a member of a class of persons on behalf of the members of that class shall be conducted as a specially managed proceeding.

Section.MarginalNote: Powers of case management judge or prothonotary

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court directs otherwise, a case management judge or a prothonotary assigned under paragraph 383(c) shall deal with all matters that arise prior to the trial or hearing of a specially managed proceeding and may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: give any directions or make any orders that are necessary for the just, most expeditious and least expensive determination of the proceeding on its merits;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notwithstanding any period provided for in these Rules, fix the period for completion of subsequent steps in the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fix and conduct any dispute resolution or pre-trial conferences that he or she considers necessary; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 50(1), hear and determine all motions arising prior to the assignment of a hearing date.

Subsection.Text: A case management judge or a prothonotary assigned under paragraph 383(c) may, at any time, order that a status review be held in accordance with this Part.

A case management judge or a prothonotary assigned under paragraph 383(c) may order that a proceeding, other than a class proceeding, cease to be conducted as a specially managed proceeding, in which case the periods set out in these Rules for taking any subsequent steps apply.

The Court may order that a proceeding, or any issue in a proceeding, be referred to a dispute resolution conference, to be conducted in accordance with rules 387 to 389 and any directions set out in the order.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Time limit for dispute resolution conference
Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, a dispute resolution conference shall be completed within 30 days.

Section.Text: A dispute resolution conference shall be conducted by a case management judge or prothonotary assigned under paragraph 383(c), who may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conduct a mediation, to assist the parties by meeting with them together or separately to encourage and facilitate discussion between them in an attempt to reach a mutually acceptable resolution of the dispute;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conduct an early neutral evaluation of a proceeding, to evaluate the relative strengths and weaknesses of the positions advanced by the parties and render a non-binding opinion as to the probable outcome of the proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conduct a mini-trial, presiding over presentation by counsel for the parties of their best case and rendering a non-binding opinion as to the probable outcome of the proceeding.

Section.Text: Discussions in a dispute resolution conference and documents prepared for the purposes of such a conference are confidential and shall not be disclosed.

Subsection.Text: Where a settlement of all or part of a proceeding is reached at a dispute resolution conference,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it shall be reduced to writing and signed by the parties or their solicitors; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a notice of settlement in Form 389 shall be filed within 10 days after the settlement is reached.

Subsection.Text: Where a settlement of only part of a proceeding is reached at a dispute resolution conference, the case management judge shall make an order setting out the issues that have not been resolved and giving such directions as he or she considers necessary for their adjudication.
Where no settlement can be reached at a dispute resolution conference, the case management judge shall record that fact on the Court file.

Section.Text: On motion, a case management judge or a prothonotary assigned under paragraph 383(c) may, by order, stay a proceeding, including a proceeding that has previously been stayed, for a period of not more than six months, on the ground that the parties have undertaken to refer the subject-matter of the proceeding to an alternative means of dispute resolution, other than a dispute resolution conference referred to in rule 386.

Section.MarginalNote: Case management judge not to preside at hearing
Section.Text: A case management judge who conducts a dispute resolution conference in an action, application or appeal shall not preside at the hearing thereof unless all parties consent.

Subsection.Text: The Court may dispose of any matter that is the subject-matter of a hearing by signing an order.

Unless it provides otherwise, an order is effective from the time that it is endorsed in writing and signed by the presiding judge or prothonotary or, in the case of an order given orally from the bench in circumstances that render it impracticable to endorse a written copy of the order, at the time it is made.

Section.Text: The Court may deliver reasons for judgment

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: orally from the bench at the conclusion of the hearing of a proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after having reserved judgment at the conclusion of a hearing, by depositing in the Registry written reasons, signed by the judge or prothonotary who delivered them.

Subsection.Text: Where the Court gives reasons, it may direct one of the parties to prepare for endorsement a draft order to implement the Court's conclusion, approved as to form and content by the other parties or, where the parties cannot agree on the form and content of the order, to bring a motion for judgment in accordance with rule 369.
On the return of a motion under subsection (1), the Court shall settle the terms of and pronounce the judgment, which shall be endorsed in writing and signed by the presiding judge or prothonotary.
Subject to subsection 36(3), the Administrator shall send without delay a copy of every order made and of any reasons given other than in open court to all parties

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by registered mail;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by electronic means, including facsimile and electronic mail; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: by any other means, as directed by the Chief Justice, likely to bring the order and any reasons to the attention of the party.

Subsection.Text: If an order and any reasons are transmitted by electronic means, the Administrator shall confirm receipt by the party and place proof of that receipt on the Court file.

Section.Text: Every order shall be recorded by the Administrator forthwith after it is made.

Subsection.Text: Within 10 days after the making of an order, or within such other time as the Court may allow, a party may serve and file a notice of motion to request that the Court, as constituted at the time the order was made, reconsider its terms on the ground that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the order does not accord with any reasons given for it; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a matter that should have been dealt with has been overlooked or accidentally omitted.

Subsection.Text: Clerical mistakes, errors or omissions in an order may at any time be corrected by the Court.
On the motion of a person against whom an order has been made,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the order has not been appealed, the court that made the order may order that it be stayed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where a notice of appeal of the order has been issued, a judge of the court that is to hear the appeal may order that it be stayed.

Subsection.Text: As a condition to granting a stay under subsection (1), a judge may require that the appellant

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide security for costs; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: do anything required to ensure that the order will be complied with when the stay is lifted.

Subsection.Text: A judge of the court that is to hear an appeal of an order that has been stayed pending appeal may set aside the stay if the judge is satisfied that the party who sought the stay is not expeditiously proceeding with the appeal or that for any other reason the order should no longer be stayed.
On motion, the Court may set aside or vary an order that was made

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ex parte; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the absence of a party who failed to appear by accident or mistake or by reason of insufficient notice of the proceeding,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: if the party against whom the order is made discloses a prima facie case why the order should not have been made.

Subsection.Text: On motion, the Court may set aside or vary an order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by reason of a matter that arose or was discovered subsequent to the making of the order; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the order was obtained by fraud.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, the setting aside or variance of an order under subsection (1) or (2) does not affect the validity or character of anything done or not done before the order was set aside or varied.
The Court shall have full discretionary power over the amount and allocation of costs and the determination of by whom they are to be paid.
Costs may be awarded to or against the Crown.
In exercising its discretion under subsection (1), the Court may consider

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the result of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amounts claimed and the amounts recovered;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the importance and complexity of the issues;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the apportionment of liability;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any written offer to settle;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any offer to contribute made under rule 421;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the amount of work;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: whether the public interest in having the proceeding litigated justifies a particular award of costs;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any conduct of a party that tended to shorten or unnecessarily lengthen the duration of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the failure by a party to admit anything that should have been admitted or to serve a request to admit;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: whether any step in the proceeding was

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: improper, vexatious or unnecessary, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: taken through negligence, mistake or excessive caution;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: whether more than one set of costs should be allowed, where two or more parties were represented by different solicitors or were represented by the same solicitor but separated their defence unnecessarily;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: whether two or more parties, represented by the same solicitor, initiated separate proceedings unnecessarily;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: whether a party who was successful in an action exaggerated a claim, including a counterclaim or third party claim, to avoid the operation of rules 292 to 299;

Paragraph.Label: (n.1)
Paragraph.Text: whether the expense required to have an expert witness give evidence was justified given

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the nature of the litigation, its public significance and any need to clarify the law,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the number, complexity or technical nature of the issues in dispute, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the amount in dispute in the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter that it considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: The Court may fix all or part of any costs by reference to Tariff B and may award a lump sum in lieu of, or in addition to, any assessed costs.

Where the Court orders that costs be assessed in accordance with Tariff B, the Court may direct that the assessment be performed under a specific column or combination of columns of the table to that Tariff.
Notwithstanding any other provision of these Rules, the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: award or refuse costs in respect of a particular issue or step in a proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: award assessed costs or a percentage of assessed costs up to and including a specified step in a proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: award all or part of costs on a solicitor-and-client basis; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: award costs against a successful party.

Subsection.Text: Costs shall be awarded to the party who is entitled to receive the costs and not to the party's solicitor, but they may be paid to the party's solicitor in trust.
The Court may award costs of a motion in an amount fixed by the Court.
Where the Court is satisfied that a motion should not have been brought or opposed, the Court shall order that the costs of the motion be payable forthwith.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise ordered by the Court or agreed by the parties, a party against whom an action, application or appeal has been discontinued or against whom a motion has been abandoned is entitled to costs forthwith, which may be assessed and the payment of which may be enforced as if judgment for the amount of the costs had been given in favour of that party.

Subsection.Text: A party may request that directions be given to the assessment officer respecting any matter referred to in rule 400,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by serving and filing a notice of motion within 30 days after judgment has been pronounced; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a motion for judgment under subsection 394(2).

Subsection.Text: A motion may be brought under paragraph (1)(a) whether or not the judgment included an order concerning costs.
A motion under paragraph (1)(a) shall be brought before the judge or prothonotary who signed the judgment.

Where costs in a proceeding are incurred improperly or without reasonable cause or are wasted by undue delay or other misconduct or default, the Court may make an order against any solicitor whom it considers to be responsible, whether personally or through a servant or agent,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: directing the solicitor personally pay the costs of a party to the proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: disallowing the costs between the solicitor and the solicitor's client.

Subsection.Text: No order under subsection (1) shall be made against a solicitor unless the solicitor has been given an opportunity to be heard.
The Court may order that notice of an order against a solicitor made under subsection (1) be given to the solicitor's client in a manner specified by the Court.

Section.Text: Costs shall be assessed by an assessment officer.

Subsection.Text: A party who is entitled to costs may obtain a notice of appointment for assessment by filing a bill of costs, a copy of the order or other document giving rise to the party’s entitlement to costs and any reasons, including dissenting reasons, given in respect of that order.
A notice of appointment for assessment and the bill of costs to be assessed shall be served on every other interested party at least 10 days before the date fixed for the assessment.

Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, party-and-party costs shall be assessed in accordance with column III of the table to Tariff B.

Subsection.Text: An assessment officer may direct the production of books and documents and give directions for the conduct of an assessment.
Where parties are liable to pay costs to each other, an assessment officer may adjust those costs by way of set-off.
An assessment officer may assess and allow, or refuse to allow, the costs of an assessment to either party.

Section.Text: In assessing costs, an assessment officer may consider the factors referred to in subsection 400(3).

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, the costs occasioned by an amendment to a pleading made without leave shall be borne by the party making the amendment.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Costs of motion to extend time
Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, the costs of a motion for an extension of time shall be borne by the party bringing the motion.

Section.Text: The costs of a motion that is abandoned or deemed to be abandoned may be assessed on the filing of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the notice of motion, together with an affidavit stating that the notice was not filed within the prescribed time or that the moving party did not appear at the hearing of the motion; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where a notice of abandonment was served, the notice of abandonment.

Section.Text: The costs of a proceeding that is discontinued may be assessed on the filing of the notice of discontinuance.

Subsection.Text: Where requested by the Attorney General of Canada, a prothonotary shall assess any costs payable by the Crown to a solicitor acting for the Crown in a proceeding.
Subsection (1) shall not be construed so as to prejudice any rights between a solicitor and a client in respect of the recovery of the solicitor's costs in any competent court.

Section.Text: A party who is dissatisfied with an assessment of an assessment officer who is not a judge may, within 10 days after the assessment, serve and file a notice of motion to request that a judge of the Federal Court review the award of costs.

Rules 416 to 418 apply, with such modifications as are necessary, to parties bringing and defending counterclaims and third party claims, to applicants and respondents in an application and to appellants and respondents in an appeal.

Subsection.Text: Where, on the motion of a defendant, it appears to the Court that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the plaintiff is ordinarily resident outside Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the plaintiff is a corporation, an unincorporated association or a nominal plaintiff and there is reason to believe that the plaintiff would have insufficient assets in Canada available to pay the costs of the defendant if ordered to do so,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the plaintiff has not provided an address in the statement of claim, or has provided an incorrect address therein, and has not satisfied the Court that the omission or misstatement was made innocently and without intention to deceive,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the plaintiff has changed address during the course of the proceeding with a view to evading the consequences of the litigation,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the plaintiff has another proceeding for the same relief pending elsewhere,

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the defendant has an order against the plaintiff for costs in the same or another proceeding that remain unpaid in whole or in part,

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: there is reason to believe that the action is frivolous and vexatious and the plaintiff would have insufficient assets in Canada available to pay the costs of the defendant, if ordered to do so, or

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: an Act of Parliament entitles the defendant to security for costs,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the Court may order the plaintiff to give security for the defendant's costs.

Subsection.Text: The Court may order that security for the costs of a defendant be given in stages, as costs are incurred.

Unless the Court orders otherwise, until the security required by an order under subsection (1) or (2) has been given, the plaintiff may not take any further step in the action, other than an appeal from that order.
A party ordinarily resident outside Canada may be ordered to give security for costs, notwithstanding that the party may be temporarily resident in Canada.

In the absence of an order under subsection (1), a plaintiff may, at any time after filing a statement of claim, pay an amount into court as security for the defendant's costs and give notice of the payment to the defendant.
The Court may, on the motion of a defendant, order a plaintiff who has paid an amount into court under subsection (5) to pay in an additional amount as security for the defendant's costs.

Section.Text: The Court may refuse to order that security for costs be given under any of paragraphs 416(1)(a) to (g) if a plaintiff demonstrates impecuniosity and the Court is of the opinion that the case has merit.

Where a person is required under these Rules or an Act of Parliament to give security for costs or for any other purpose, unless otherwise ordered by the Court or required by that Act, the person may do so

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by paying the required amount into court; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by filing a bond for the required amount that has been approved by an order of the Court.

Section.Text: Rules 420 and 421 apply, with such modifications as are necessary, to parties bringing and defending counterclaims and third party claims, to applicants and respondents in an application and to appellants and respondents in an appeal.

Section.MarginalNote: Consequences of failure to accept plaintiff’s offer

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise ordered by the Court and subject to subsection (3), where a plaintiff makes a written offer to settle and obtains a judgment as favourable or more favourable than the terms of the offer to settle, the plaintiff is entitled to party-and-party costs to the date of service of the offer and costs calculated at double that rate, but not double disbursements, after that date.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Consequences of failure to accept defendant’s offer
Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise ordered by the Court and subject to subsection (3), where a defendant makes a written offer to settle,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the plaintiff obtains a judgment less favourable than the terms of the offer to settle, the plaintiff is entitled to party-and-party costs to the date of service of the offer and the defendant shall be entitled to costs calculated at double that rate, but not double disbursements, from that date to the date of judgment; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the plaintiff fails to obtain judgment, the defendant is entitled to party-and-party costs to the date of the service of the offer and to costs calculated at double that rate, but not double disbursements, from that date to the date of judgment.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply unless the offer to settle

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is made at least 14 days before the commencement of the hearing or trial; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is not withdrawn and does not expire before the commencement of the hearing or trial.

Subsection.Text: In circumstances where a written offer to settle does not provide for the settlement of the issue of costs, if a party requests the Court to consider rule 420, the Court, in ascertaining whether the judgment granted is more or less favourable than the offer to settle, shall not have regard to costs awarded in the judgment or that would otherwise be awarded.

For greater certainty, if a written offer to settle that does not provide for the settlement of the issue of costs is accepted, a party to the offer may apply to the Court for an order determining costs.

Section.Text: Subsection 420(2) applies to a third party, or to one of two or more defendants who are alleged to be jointly and severally liable to the plaintiff in respect of a claim, who makes a written offer to other defendants or third parties to contribute toward a settlement of the claim.

No communication respecting an offer to settle or offer to contribute shall be made to the Court, other than to a case management judge or prothonotary assigned under rule 383(c) or to a judge or prothonotary at a pre-trial conference, until all questions of liability and the relief to be granted, other than costs, have been determined.
All matters relating to the enforcement of orders shall be brought before the Federal Court.

Subsection.Text: Where under an Act of Parliament the Court is authorized to enforce an order of a tribunal and no other procedure is required by or under that Act, the order may be enforced under this Part.

An order referred to in subsection (1) shall be filed together with a certificate from the tribunal, or an affidavit of a person authorized to file such an order, attesting to the authenticity of the order.

Section.MarginalNote: Enforcement of order for payment of money
Section.Text: An order for the payment of money may be enforced by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a writ of seizure and sale in Form 425A;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: garnishment proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a charging order;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the appointment of a receiver; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a person referred to in rule 429, a writ of sequestration in Form 425B.

Section.Text: A person who has obtained an order for the payment of money may conduct an oral examination of the judgment debtor or, if the judgment debtor is a body corporate, of an officer thereof, as to the assets of the judgment debtor.

Subsection.Text: An order for possession of real property or immoveables may be enforced by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a writ of possession, in Form 427; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a person referred to in rule 429, an order of committal or a writ of sequestration, or both.

Subsection.Text: A writ of possession shall be issued only if the Court is satisfied that every person in possession of the whole or any part of the real property or immoveables has received notice sufficient to enable the person to apply to the Court for any relief to which the person may be entitled.

Section.MarginalNote: Delivery of personal property and movables

Subsection.Text: An order for the delivery of personal property or movables that does not give the person against whom the order is made the alternative of paying an amount equal to the value of the personal property or movables may be enforced by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a writ of delivery to recover the personal property or movables, in Form 428; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a person referred to in rule 429, an order of committal or a writ of sequestration, or both.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Delivery of personal property or movables or amount equal to value
Subsection.Text: An order for the delivery of personal property or movables or the payment of an amount equal to their value may be enforced by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a writ of delivery to recover the personal property or movables or an amount equal to their value, in Form 428; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a person referred to in rule 429, a writ of sequestration.

Section.MarginalNote: Writ of sequestration and order of committal

Subsection.Text: Where a person who is required by an order to perform an act within a specified time refuses or neglects to do so within that time, or where a person disobeys an order to abstain from doing an act, the order may, with the leave of the Court, be enforced by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a writ of sequestration against the property of the person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the person is a corporation, a writ of sequestration against the property of any director or officer of the corporation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), in respect of an order other than for payment of money, an order of committal against the person or, where the person is a body corporate, against any director or officer of the corporation.

Subsection.Text: Where under an order requiring the delivery of personal property or movables a person who is liable to execution has the alternative of paying an amount equal to the value of the personal property or movables, the order shall not be enforced by an order of committal.

Section.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, an order shall not be enforced against a person under rule 429 unless the order has been personally served on the person.
Where a person does not comply with an order to perform an act, without prejudice to the powers of the Court to punish the person for contempt, on motion, the Court may order that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the required act be performed by the person by whom the order was obtained or by another person appointed by the Court; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the non-complying person pay the costs incurred in the performance of the act, ascertained in such a manner as the Court may direct, and that a writ of execution be issued against the non-complying person for those costs.

Section.Text: Where a person who is entitled to relief under an order subject to the fulfilment of a condition fails to fulfil that condition, the person is deemed to have abandoned the benefit of the order and, unless the Court orders otherwise, any other interested person may take any step that is warranted by the order or that might have been taken if the order had not been made.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2) and rules 434 and 435, a person entitled to execution may obtain a writ of execution by filing a requisition for its issuance.

A writ of execution shall be issued only if, at the time a requisition therefor is filed, any period specified in the order for the payment of money or for the doing of an act required under the order has expired.
A writ of execution for the recovery of money shall be endorsed with a direction to the sheriff to levy

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the amount of money due and payable that is sought to be recovered;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any interest thereon that is sought to be recovered, from the date of the order; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any sheriff's fees and costs of execution.

Subsection.Text: A writ of execution to enforce an order shall not be issued without the leave of the Court if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: six or more years have elapsed since the date of the order;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a change has taken place, by death or otherwise, in the persons entitled or liable to execution under the order;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: under the order a person is entitled to relief subject to the fulfilment of a condition that is alleged to have been fulfilled; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any personal property or movables sought to be seized under the writ are in the possession of a receiver appointed by the Court or of a sequestrator.

Subsection.Text: An order granting leave under subsection (1) expires one year after it is made.

Section.MarginalNote: Leave to issue writ in aid
Section.Text: A writ of execution in aid of another writ of execution shall not be issued without the leave of the Court.

Section.MarginalNote: Ex parte motion for leave to issue writ
Section.Text: A motion for leave to issue a writ of execution under subsection 434(1) or rule 435 may be made ex parte.

Subsection.Text: A writ of execution is valid for six years after its date of issuance.

On motion, where a writ has not been wholly executed, the Court may, before the writ would otherwise expire, order that the validity of the writ, including a writ the validity of which has previously been extended, be extended for a further period of six years.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Conditions for execution of extended writ
Subsection.Text: Before execution of a writ the validity of which has been extended by an order under subsection (2),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the writ shall be endorsed with a notice setting out the date on which the order was made; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the moving party shall serve a certified copy of the order on the sheriff to whom the writ is directed.

Subsection.Text: A writ the validity of which has been extended under subsection (2) continues without interruption.

Section.Text: Before executing a writ of execution, a sheriff to whom the writ is directed may require the person at whose instance it was issued to make an advance, or to give security, sufficient to cover the costs of execution.

Subsection.Text: A person at whose instance a writ of execution is issued may serve a notice on the sheriff to whom the writ is directed requiring the sheriff, within such time as may be specified in the notice, to endorse on the writ a statement of the manner in which the sheriff has executed it and to send a copy of the statement to the person.
Where a sheriff fails to comply with a notice served under subsection (1), the person by whom it was served may apply to the Court for an order directing the sheriff to comply with the notice.

A person at whose instance a writ of execution is issued or a sheriff may seek directions from the Court concerning any issue not addressed by these Rules that arises from the enforcement of an order.

Section.Text: Writs of execution of different types may be issued to enforce a single order, where the terms of the order so require.

Section.MarginalNote: Leave to issue writ of sequestration

Subsection.Text: No writ of sequestration shall be issued without leave of a judge.
Notice of a motion for leave to issue a writ of sequestration shall be personally served on the person against whose property it is sought to issue the writ.

Section.MarginalNote: Multiple writs of seizure and sale

Subsection.Text: A person who is entitled to enforce an order by a writ of seizure and sale may request the issuance of two or more such writs directed to the sheriffs of different geographical areas, either at the same time or at different times, to enforce the order, but no greater total amount shall be levied under all such writs than would be authorized to be levied under a single writ.

Where a person requests the issuance of two or more writs of seizure and sale directed to sheriffs of different geographical areas to enforce the same order, the person shall inform each sheriff of the issuance of the other writ or writs.

Section.Text: Where the payment of an ascertained sum of money and an unascertained sum of money or costs is ordered, if, at the time when the ascertained sum becomes payable, the unascertained sum or costs have not been assessed, the person who is entitled to enforce the order may request the issuance of a writ of seizure and sale to enforce payment of the ascertained sum and, after the unascertained sum or costs have been assessed, may request the issuance of a second writ to enforce payment thereof.

Where an order for payment of less than $200 does not entitle the plaintiff to costs against the person against whom a writ of seizure and sale to enforce the order is issued, the writ may not authorize the sheriff to whom it is directed to levy any fees or costs of execution.
Any interest of a judgment debtor in property may be sold under a writ of seizure and sale.

Section.MarginalNote: Sale of real property or immoveables
Section.Text: Real property or immoveables shall not be sold under a writ of seizure and sale within a shorter period than that provided for by the laws of the province in which the real property or immoveables are situated or any longer period ordered by the Court.
Property is bound for the purpose of execution of an order as of the date of the delivery to the sheriff of a writ of seizure and sale.

In seizing, advertising for sale or selling property, a sheriff shall, except as otherwise provided in the writ or in these Rules, follow the laws applicable to the execution of similar writs issued by a superior court of the province in which the property was seized.

Subsection.Text: Subject to rules 452 and 456, on the ex parte motion of a judgment creditor, the Court may order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a debt owing or accruing from a person in Canada to a judgment debtor, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a debt owing or accruing from a person outside Canada to a judgment debtor, where the debt is one for which the person might be sued in Canada by the judgment debtor,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: be attached to answer the judgment debt; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that the person attend, at a specified time and place, to show cause why the person should not pay to the judgment creditor the debt or any lesser amount sufficient to satisfy the judgment.

Subsection.Text: An order to show cause made under subsection (1) shall be served, at least seven days before the time appointed for showing cause,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the garnishee personally; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: unless the Court directs otherwise, on the judgment debtor.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Debts bound as of time of service
Subsection.Text: Subject to rule 452, an order under subsection (1) binds the debts attached as of the time of service of the order.

Section.Text: A garnishee may admit liability and pay into court a debt due to a judgment debtor, or as much thereof as is sufficient to satisfy the judgment, notice of which shall be given to the judgment creditor.

Subsection.Text: Where a garnishee has not made a payment into court under rule 450 and does not dispute the debt claimed to be due to the judgment debtor, or does not appear pursuant to a show cause order made under subsection 449(1), on motion, the Court may make an order for payment to the judgment creditor or payment into court of the debt.

Where a debt owed to a judgment debtor is not payable at the time an order is sought under subsection 449(1), an order may be made for payment of the debt to the judgment creditor under subsection (1) as at the time the debt becomes payable.
An order under subsection (1) may be enforced in the same manner as any other order for the payment of money.

Section.Text: Where a debt due or accruing to a judgment debtor is in respect of wages or salary, no portion thereof that is exempt from seizure or attachment under the law of the province where the debt is payable shall be attached under an order made under rule 449.

Where a garnishee disputes liability to pay a debt claimed to be due or accruing to the judgment debtor, the Court may summarily determine any question of liability of the garnishee or order that it be determined in such a manner as the Court may direct.

A payment made under rule 450 by a garnishee or in compliance with an order under rule 449, and any execution levied against a garnishee under such an order, constitutes a valid discharge of the garnishee's liability to the judgment debtor to the extent of the amount paid or levied, notwithstanding that the attachment is later set aside or that the order from which it arose is later reversed.

Section.MarginalNote: Order for other person to attend

Subsection.Text: If, on a motion under rule 449, it is brought to the notice of the Court that a person other than the judgment debtor has or claims to have an interest in the debt sought to be attached, the Court may order the person to attend before the Court and state the nature of his or her interest.

After hearing a person who attends before the Court under an order made under subsection (1), the Court may summarily determine the questions at issue between the claimants or order that it be determined in such a manner as the Court may direct.

Where money is standing to the credit of a judgment debtor in court, the judgment creditor shall not bring a motion under rule 449 in respect of the money, but may bring a motion for an order that the money, or a lesser amount sufficient to satisfy the order sought to be enforced and the costs of the motion, be paid to the judgment creditor.
Money to which a motion under subsection (1) relates shall not be paid out of court until after the determination of the motion.
Unless the Court directs otherwise, notice of a motion under subsection (1) shall be served on the judgment debtor and filed at least seven days before the day fixed for the hearing of the motion.

Section.Text: The costs of a motion under rule 449 or 456 and of any related proceedings shall, unless the Court directs otherwise, be retained by the judgment creditor out of the money recovered under the order and in priority to the judgment debt.

Section.MarginalNote: Order for interim charge and show cause

Subsection.Text: On the ex parte motion of a judgment creditor, the Court may, for the purpose of enforcing an order for the payment of an ascertained sum of money,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make an order imposing an interim charge for securing payment of that sum and any interest thereon

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on real property or immoveables, or on an interest in real property or immoveables, of a judgment debtor, in Form 458A, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on any interest to which the judgment debtor is beneficially entitled in any shares, bonds or other securities specified in the order, in Form 458B; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: order the judgment debtor to show cause, at a specified time and place, why the charge should not be made absolute.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court directs otherwise, an order made under subsection (1) shall be served on the judgment debtor and, where the order relates to property referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(ii), on the corporation, government or other person or entity by whom the securities were issued, at least seven days before the time appointed for the hearing.
At a show cause hearing referred to in paragraph 458(1)(b), the Court shall make the interim charge absolute, in Form 459, or discharge it.
A charge made absolute has the same effect, and is enforceable in the same manner, as a charge made by the judgment debtor.

Section.Text: No disposition by a judgment debtor of an interest in property subject to an interim or absolute charge under rule 458 or 459 is valid against the judgment creditor.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court orders otherwise, no person or entity on whom an order was served under subsection 458(2) shall permit the transfer of any security specified in the order or pay to any person a dividend or any interest payable thereon.

If, after service of an order under rule 458, a person or entity on whom it was served makes a transfer or payment prohibited by subsection (1), the person or entity shall be liable to pay to the judgment creditor an amount equal to the value of the security transferred or the amount of the payment made, as the case may be, or as much of it as is sufficient to satisfy the judgment debt.

Section.MarginalNote: Discharge or variance of charging order
Section.Text: The Court may, on the motion of a judgment debtor or any other person with an interest in property subject to an interim or absolute charge under rule 458 or 459, at any time, discharge or vary the charging order on such terms as to costs as it considers just.

Section.MarginalNote: Charge on interest in money paid into court

Subsection.Text: On motion, the Court may, for the purpose of enforcing an order for the payment of an ascertained sum of money, by order, impose a charge for securing payment of the amount due under the order, and of any interest thereon, on any interest to which the judgment debtor is beneficially entitled in any money paid into court that is identified in the order.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Application of rules re other charging orders
Subsection.Text: Subsection 458(1) and rules 460 and 462 apply, with such modifications as are necessary, to an order made under this rule.

Section.Text: On motion, a judge may grant an injunction ancillary or incidental to a charging order under rule 458 or appoint a receiver to enforce a charge imposed by such an order.

Subsection.Text: The Court, on the motion of a person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: who has a mortgage or charge on the interest of another person in money paid into court,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to whom such an interest has been assigned, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: who is a judgment creditor of a person entitled to such an interest,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: may make an order prohibiting the transfer, delivery, payment or other dealing with all or any part of the money, or any income thereon, without prior notice to the moving party.

Subsection.Text: Notice of a motion under subsection (1) shall be served on every person whose interest may be affected by the order sought.
On a motion under subsection (1), the Court may order the moving party to pay the costs of any party or of any other person interested in the money in question.

Section.Text: Subject to rule 467, a person is guilty of contempt of Court who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at a hearing fails to maintain a respectful attitude, remain silent or refrain from showing approval or disapproval of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: disobeys a process or order of the Court;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: acts in such a way as to interfere with the orderly administration of justice, or to impair the authority or dignity of the Court;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is an officer of the Court and fails to perform his or her duty; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is a sheriff or bailiff and does not execute a writ forthwith or does not make a return thereof or, in executing it, infringes a rule the contravention of which renders the sheriff or bailiff liable to a penalty.

Subsection.Text: Subject to rule 468, before a person may be found in contempt of Court, the person alleged to be in contempt shall be served with an order, made on the motion of a person who has an interest in the proceeding or at the Court's own initiative, requiring the person alleged to be in contempt

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to appear before a judge at a time and place stipulated in the order;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to be prepared to hear proof of the act with which the person is charged, which shall be described in the order with sufficient particularity to enable the person to know the nature of the case against the person; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to be prepared to present any defence that the person may have.

Subsection.Text: A motion for an order under subsection (1) may be made ex parte.
An order may be made under subsection (1) if the Court is satisfied that there is a prima facie case that contempt has been committed.
An order under subsection (1) shall be personally served, together with any supporting documents, unless otherwise ordered by the Court.

Section.MarginalNote: Contempt in presence of a judge
Section.Text: In a case of urgency, a person may be found in contempt of Court for an act committed in the presence of a judge and condemned at once, if the person has been called on to justify his or her behaviour.
A finding of contempt shall be based on proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court directs otherwise, evidence on a motion for a contempt order, other than an order under subsection 467(1), shall be oral.
A person alleged to be in contempt may not be compelled to testify.

Section.Text: Where the Court considers it necessary, it may request the assistance of the Attorney General of Canada in relation to any proceedings for contempt.
Where a person is found to be in contempt, a judge may order that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person be imprisoned for a period of less than five years or until the person complies with the order;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person be imprisoned for a period of less than five years if the person fails to comply with the order;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person pay a fine;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person do or refrain from doing any act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a person referred to in rule 429, the person's property be sequestered; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the person pay costs.

Section.MarginalNote: To whom process may be issued

Subsection.Text: Where there is no sheriff or a sheriff is unable or unwilling to act, a process, including a warrant for arrest of property under rule 481, may be issued to any person to whom a process of a superior court of the province in which the process is to be executed could be issued.

Where a process is issued to a sheriff, it may, at the sheriff's direction, be executed by a person authorized under provincial law to execute the process of a superior court of the province in which the process is to be executed.
Where an order made against the Crown for the payment of money for costs or otherwise is executory and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where no appeal of the order has been instituted, the time allowed by law for an appeal from the order has expired, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where there has been an appeal from the order, the order has been affirmed or varied on appeal,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the Administrator shall issue a certificate of judgment accordingly.

Subsection.Text: A certificate issued under subsection (1) shall be transmitted by the Administrator to the office of the Deputy Attorney General of Canada.
This Part applies to Admiralty actions.
Except to the extent that they are inconsistent with this Part, the rules applicable to other actions apply to Admiralty actions.

Section.Text: In this Part, designated officer means an officer of the Registry designated by an order of the Court.

Heading.TitleText: Actions In Rem and In Personam

Subsection.Text: Admiralty actions may be in rem or in personam, or both.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Style of cause of action in rem
Subsection.Text: The style of cause of an action in rem shall be in Form 477.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Style of cause of action in personam
Subsection.Text: The style of cause of an action in personam shall be as provided for in subsection 67(2).
In an action in rem, a plaintiff shall include as a defendant the owners and all others interested in the subject-matter of the action.

Section.MarginalNote: Action against more than one ship
Section.Text: In an action against more than one ship in accordance with subsection 43(8) of the Act, each ship shall be named as a defendant in the statement of claim.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the statement of claim in an action in rem shall be served

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a ship or cargo or other property on board a ship, by attaching a certified copy of the statement of claim to some conspicuous part of the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of cargo or other property that is not on board a ship, by attaching a certified copy of the statement of claim to the cargo or property;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of freight,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if the cargo in respect of which the freight is owing is on board a ship, by attaching a certified copy of the statement of claim to a conspicuous part of the ship,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the cargo in respect of which the freight is owing is not on board a ship, by attaching a certified copy of the statement of claim to the cargo, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: if monies payable for the freight are in the possession of a person, by personal service of the statement of claim on that person; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of any proceeds paid into court in another proceeding, by filing a certified copy of the statement of claim in that proceeding.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Alternate service of statement of claim
Subsection.Text: If access cannot be obtained to property in respect of which a statement of claim is to be served under subsection (1), the statement of claim may be served personally on a person who appears to be in charge of the property.

An action in rem against a ship or other thing named as a defendant in the action may be defended only by a person who claims to be the owner of the ship or thing or to be otherwise interested therein.
A defence filed by a person referred to in subsection (1) shall disclose the interest that the person claims in the ship or thing.

Section.MarginalNote: Warrant for the arrest of property

Subsection.Text: A designated officer may issue a warrant for the arrest of property in an action in rem, in Form 481, at any time after the filing of a statement of claim.
A party seeking a warrant under subsection (1) shall file an affidavit, entitled "Affidavit to Lead Warrant", stating

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address and occupation of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the claim and the basis for invoking the in rem jurisdiction of the Court;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that the claim has not been satisfied;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the property to be arrested and, where the property is a ship, the name and nationality of the ship and the port to which it belongs; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where, pursuant to subsection 43(8) of the Act, the warrant is sought against a ship that is not the subject of the action, that the deponent has reasonable grounds to believe that the ship against which the warrant is sought is beneficially owned by the person who is the owner of the ship that is the subject of the action.

Subsection.Text: A warrant issued under subsection 481(1), the Affidavit to Lead Warrant and the statement of claim in the action shall be served together by a sheriff in the manner set out in rule 479, whereupon the property subject to the warrant is deemed to be arrested.
Proof of service of the documents referred to in subsection (1) shall be filed forthwith after the documents are served.

Subject to subsection (2), possession of, and responsibility for, property arrested under subsection 482(1) does not vest in the sheriff but continues in the person in possession of the property immediately before the arrest.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Order for possession of arrested property
Subsection.Text: The Court may order a sheriff to take possession of arrested property on condition that a party assume responsibility for any costs or fees incurred or payable in carrying out the order and give security satisfactory to the Court for the payment thereof.

Section.Text: No property arrested under a warrant shall be moved without leave of the Court or the consent of all parties and caveators.
On motion, the Court may fix the amount of bail to be given for the release of arrested property.

Subsection.Text: Unless the parties agree otherwise, bail shall consist of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the guaranty of a bank;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the bond of a surety company licensed to do business in Canada or to furnish security bonds in the part of Canada where the bond is executed, in Form 486A; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a bail bond in Form 486A.

Subsection.Text: A party who intends to give bail in the form of a bond referred to in paragraph (1)(b) or (c) shall serve and file a notice of bail, in Form 486B, at least 24 hours before filing the bond.
An adverse party or caveator who is not satisfied with the sufficiency of a bond set out in a notice of bail shall serve and file a notice of objection in Form 486C.
Any question as to the form of bail or the sufficiency of a surety may be determined by a designated officer or referred by that officer to the Court.
Unless a caveat has been filed under subsection 493(2), a designated officer may issue a release of arrested property in Form 487

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on payment into court of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the amount claimed,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the appraised value of the property arrested, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: where cargo is arrested for freight only, the amount of the freight, verified by affidavit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if bail has been given in an amount fixed under rule 485 and in accordance with subsections 486(1) and (2) and no objection under subsection 486(3) is outstanding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on the consent in writing of the party at whose instance the property was arrested; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on the discontinuance or dismissal of the action in respect of which the property was arrested.

Subsection.Text: Where a release is sought under subsection (1), a designated officer may refer the matter to a judge or prothonotary.
On motion, the Court may, at any time, order the release of arrested property.

Where, pursuant to subsection 43(8) of the Act, a ship that is not the subject of an action has been arrested, any owner or other person interested in the ship may bring a motion to the Court for the release of the ship, and if it is found that the ship is not beneficially owned by the person who is the owner of the ship that is the subject of the action, the Court shall order its release without the taking of bail.

Where on a motion under subsection (2) the Court is satisfied that the action in which the ship has been arrested is for a claim referred to in any of paragraphs 22(2)(a) to (c) of the Act, the Court may order the release of the ship without the taking of bail.

Section.Text: Property shall be released from arrest on service of a release on the sheriff and payment of all fees and costs of the sheriff in respect of the arrest or custody of the property.

Subsection.Text: On motion, the Court may order, in respect of property under arrest, that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the property be appraised and sold, or sold without appraisal, by public auction or private contract;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the property be advertised for sale in accordance with such directions as may be set out in the order, which may include a direction that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: offers to purchase be under seal and addressed to the sheriff,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: offers to purchase all be opened at the same time in open court, that the parties be notified of that time and that the sale be made pursuant to an order of the Court made at that time or after the parties have had an opportunity to be heard,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the sale not necessarily be to the highest or any other bidder, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: after the opening of the offers and after hearing from the parties, if it is doubtful that a fair price has been offered, the amount of the highest offer be communicated to the other persons who made offers or to some other class of persons or that other steps be taken to obtain a higher offer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the property be sold without advertisement;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an agent be employed to sell the property, subject to such conditions as are stipulated in the order or subject to subsequent approval by the Court, on such terms as to compensation of the agent as may be stipulated in the order;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any steps be taken for the safety and preservation of the property;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: where the property is deteriorating in value, it be sold forthwith;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: where the property is on board a ship, it be removed or discharged;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: where the property is perishable, it be disposed of on such terms as the Court may order; or

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the property be inspected in accordance with rule 249.

Subsection.Text: The appraisal or sale of property under arrest shall be effected under the authority of a commission addressed to the sheriff in Form 490.
Property sold under subsection (1) is free of any liens under Canadian maritime law.
As soon as possible after the execution of a commission referred to in subsection (2), the sheriff shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: file the commission with a return setting out the manner in which it was executed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: pay into court the proceeds of the sale; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: file the sheriff's accounts and vouchers in support thereof.

Subsection.Text: An assessment officer shall assess the sheriff's accounts and report the amount that the assessment officer considers should be allowed.
Any party or caveator who is interested in the proceeds of sale referred to in subsection (4) may be heard on an assessment under subsection (5).
On motion, the Court may review an assessment done under subsection (5).

Section.MarginalNote: Payment out of money paid into court
Section.Text: On a motion for payment out of any money paid into court under subsection 490(4), the Court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine the rights of all claimants thereto;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: order payment of all or part of the money to any claimant; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: order immediate payment of any fees or costs of the sheriff in connection with the arrest, custody, appraisal or sale of property, including expenses incurred in maintaining the property between the time of arrest and the sale of the property.

Subsection.Text: The Court may, in making an order under rule 490 or 491 or at any time thereafter, give directions as to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notice to be given to possible claimants to the proceeds of sale;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: advertising for other such claimants;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the time within which claimants must file their claims; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the procedure to be followed in determining the rights of the parties.

Subsection.Text: A claim that is not made within the time limited and in the manner prescribed by an order of the Court under subsection (1) is barred, and the Court may proceed to determine other claims and distribute the money among the parties entitled thereto without reference to any claim so barred.

A person who desires to prevent the arrest of property shall serve and file a caveat warrant in Form 493A undertaking to give, within three days after being required to do so, bail in respect of any action that has been, or may be, brought against the property.
A person who desires to prevent the release of any property under arrest shall serve and file a caveat release in Form 493B.
A person who desires to prevent the payment of money out of court shall serve and file a caveat payment in Form 493C.
A caveat under subsection (1), (2) or (3) shall be served on all parties and caveators.
Where a person filing a caveat under this rule is not a party to the action, the caveat shall state the person's name and provide an address for service.

A person at whose instance a warrant is issued for the arrest of property in respect of which there is a caveat warrant outstanding is liable to payment of all resulting costs and damages, unless the person can satisfy the Court that the person should not be liable therefor.
A person who files a caveat release or caveat payment is liable to payment of all resulting costs and damages, unless the person can satisfy the Court that the person should not be liable therefor.
A caveat expires one year after the day on which it was filed.
A new caveat may be served and filed before or after the expiration of an existing caveat.
A person who has filed a caveat may withdraw it at any time by filing a notice in Form 495.
On motion, the Court may order that a caveat be set aside.

Section.MarginalNote: Application under s 33(1) of the Marine Liability Act

Subsection.Text: A party bringing an application under subsection 33(1) of the Marine Liability Act shall bring it as an action against those claimants whose identity is known to the party.

A party referred to in subsection (1) may bring an ex parte motion for directions respecting service on possible claimants where the number of possible claimants is large or the identity of all possible claimants is unknown to the party.

Section.Text: A claimant who did not have notice of an action under subsection 496(1) may, within 10 days after obtaining notice of an order made under subsection 496(2), serve and file a notice of motion requesting to be added as a party to the action.

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise ordered by the Court, in an action in respect of a collision between ships,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the statement of claim need not contain any more particulars concerning the collision than are necessary to identify it to the other parties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the statement of defence need not contain any particulars concerning the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a preliminary act shall accompany a statement of claim and a statement of defence or be filed within 10 days after the filing of the statement of claim or the statement of defence, as the case may be; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a preliminary act shall be contained in a sealed envelope bearing the style of cause.

Subsection.Text: A preliminary act shall state

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the time of the collision at the location of the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the ships that collided;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of the ship of the party filing the preliminary act,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the ship,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the port of registry of the ship,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the master of the ship at time of the collision,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of the person who was in command at the time of the collision and during the period immediately before the collision,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the names and addresses of any persons keeping lookout at the time of the collision and during the period immediately before the collision,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the course of the ship or, if the ship was stationary, its heading, at the time when the other ship was first seen or immediately before any measures were taken with reference to the other ship's presence, whichever was the earlier,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the speed of the ship through the water at the time when the other ship was first seen or immediately before any measures were taken with reference to the other ship's presence, whichever was the earlier,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: any alteration made to course after the time referred to in subparagraph (vi) or during the period immediately before the collision, and the time at which the alteration was made,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: any alteration made to the speed of the ship after the time referred to in subparagraph (vii) or during the period immediately before the collision, and the time at which the alteration was made,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: any measure taken to avoid the collision, and the time at which the measure was taken,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: any sound or visual signals given, and the time at which the signals were given, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: the lights carried by the ship and the lights it was showing at the time of the collision and during the period immediately before the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of every other ship involved in the collision,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the ship,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ship's distance and bearing at the time when its echo was first observed by radar by a person on the ship of the party filing the preliminary act,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ship's distance, bearing and approximate heading when it was first seen by a person on the ship of the party filing the preliminary act,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the lights the ship was showing when it was first seen by a person on the ship of the party filing the preliminary act,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the lights the ship was showing from the time referred to in subparagraph (iv) to the time of the collision,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: any alteration made to the ship's course after it was first seen by a person on the ship of the party filing the preliminary act, and the time at which the alteration was made,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: any alteration made to the ship's speed after it was first seen by a person on the ship of the party filing the preliminary act, and the time at which the alteration was made,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: any measure that the ship took to avoid the collision, and the time at which the measure was taken,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: any sound or visual signals given, and the time at which the signals were given, and

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: any fault or default attributed to the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the state of the weather at the time of the collision and during the period immediately before the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the extent of visibility at the time of the collision and during the period immediately before the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the state, direction and force of the tide, or of the current if the collision occurred in non-tidal waters, at the time of the collision and during the period immediately before the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the direction and force of the wind at the time of the collision and during the period immediately before the collision;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the parts of each ship that first came into contact; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the approximate angle, as illustrated by an appropriate sketch annexed to the preliminary act, between the ships at the moment of contact.

Subsection.Text: The contents of a preliminary act shall be set out in parallel columns and, wherever possible, stated in numerical values.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Opening of envelopes containing preliminary acts
Subsection.Text: The Administrator shall open the envelopes containing the preliminary acts after the pleadings have been closed and all preliminary acts have been filed or, with the consent of all parties, at any other time.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Order to open envelopes containing preliminary acts
Subsection.Text: The Court may, on motion brought after all preliminary acts have been filed but before pleadings have been closed, order that the Administrator open the envelopes containing the preliminary acts.

On the opening of an envelope containing a preliminary act, the Administrator shall endorse the preliminary act with the date on which it was filed, the date on which the envelope was opened and the date on which any order was made, or consent filed, pursuant to which the envelope was opened.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deemed part of statement of claim or defence
Subsection.Text: A preliminary act shall be read with and form a part of the statement of claim or statement of defence, as the case may be, as though it were a schedule thereto.

Section.Text: Notwithstanding rule 416, a seaman suing for wages or for the loss of clothing and effects in a collision shall not be ordered to give security for costs.

Notwithstanding subsection 236(2), in an action in respect of a collision between ships, a defendant may examine the plaintiff for discovery only after filing a statement of defence and preliminary act.

Heading.Label: PART 14
Heading.TitleText: Transitional, Repeal and Coming into Force

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), these Rules apply to all proceedings, including further steps taken in proceedings that were commenced before the coming into force of these Rules.

The Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Appeal or the Federal Court, as the case may be, may, by order, direct that rule 380 shall not apply to certain proceedings or classes of proceedings before their court that are pending on the coming into force of these Rules until a date or dates set out in the order.

Every officer of the Court appointed under the Federal Court Rules prior to the coming into force of these Rules shall continue to act as if appointed under these Rules, until the appointment is revoked or another person is appointed in that officer's place.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Taxing officers continued as assessment officers
Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), a reference in these Rules to an assessment officer shall be construed as a reference to a taxing officer appointed under the Federal Court Rules prior to the coming into force of these Rules.

Section.Text: These Rules come into force on April 25, 1998.
